English Pronounciation: Khao hu sai thalu hu khwa
Idiom meaning in English: Telling or teaching is ineffective, not listening carefully
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เข้าหูซ้ายทะลุหูขวา" translates to "in one ear and out the other" in English. It describes a situation where someone hears something but does not pay attention or remember it. The imagery for this idiom could depict a person with sound waves or words entering their left ear and immediately exiting their right ear, symbolizing the lack of retention or attention to what was heard.

Actual idiom: เขียนด้วยมือลบด้วยตีน
Literal Translation: Write by hand, erase with foot
English Pronounciation: Khian duai mue lop duai tin
Idiom meaning in English: Praise and then destroy later
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เขียนด้วยมือลบด้วยตีน" translates to "written with the hand, erased with the foot." It describes a situation where someone makes a promise or commitment and then carelessly or disrespectfully breaks it. The imagery suggests the act of writing something carefully with one's hand, only to have it thoughtlessly erased or undone with one's foot, symbolizing a lack of respect or consideration for one's own words or actions.

Actual idiom: เขียว ๆ แดง ๆ
Idiom meaning in English: Group of women dressed in different colors
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "เขียว ๆ แดง ๆ" (pronounced "khiow khiow daeng daeng") translates to "green green, red red" in English. It is often used to describe something that appears attractive or appealing on the outside but may not be as desirable or valuable upon closer inspection. The imagery of green and red can be associated with fruits that look ripe and delicious but might be sour or unripe inside. 

For an image based on this idiom, you could depict a vibrant, colorful fruit that looks enticing from the outside but has a less appealing interior when cut open. This visual metaphor captures the essence of the idiom, highlighting the contrast between outward appearances and inner reality.

Idiom meaning in English: Subordinate, someone who works on your behalf
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "แขนขา" (khaen kha) translates to "arms and legs" in English. It is often used to describe someone who is a close and indispensable helper or assistant, much like how arms and legs are essential parts of the body. For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a person surrounded by supportive friends or colleagues, symbolizing their crucial role in helping the person function effectively, akin to how arms and legs support the body.

Actual idiom: แขนซ้ายแขนขวา
Idiom meaning in English: Subordinates or those who are the driving force are like the left and right arms.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "แขนซ้ายแขนขวา" translates to "left arm, right arm" in English. It symbolizes the idea of mutual support and cooperation, much like how both arms work together to accomplish tasks. An image representing this idiom could depict two arms, one left and one right, working together harmoniously to achieve a common goal, emphasizing unity and collaboration.

Idiom meaning in English: Heartbreak due to disappointment in love, etc.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ไข้ใจ" (pronounced "khai jai") translates to "heart sickness" or "sickness of the heart" in English. It metaphorically describes a state of emotional distress or heartache, often due to unrequited love, deep sadness, or emotional turmoil. The imagery associated with this idiom might include a person clutching their chest, a broken heart, or a somber, introspective scene that conveys deep emotional pain.

Idiom meaning in English: Things that need to be handled with extreme care and attention
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ไข่ในหิน" (pronounced "kai nai hin") translates to "an egg in a rock." It describes something or someone that is extremely delicate, fragile, or precious, requiring careful handling and protection. The imagery suggests an egg, which is inherently fragile, being encased in a rock, emphasizing the need for extra caution and care.

Actual idiom: คงเส้นคงวา
Idiom meaning in English: Consistently
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'คงเส้นคงวา' translates to "consistent" or "steady" in English. It describes someone or something that maintains a steady, reliable, and unchanging course over time. For an image representation, you might consider depicting a straight, unwavering path or a person walking steadily along a road, symbolizing reliability and consistency.

Actual idiom: คดในข้องอในกระดูก
English Pronounciation: Khot nai khong ngo nai kraduk
Idiom meaning in English: Has a deceitful nature
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คดในข้องอในกระดูก" translates to "crooked in the bamboo tube, bent in the bone." It describes someone who is inherently deceitful or dishonest, suggesting that their dishonesty is deeply ingrained and part of their nature. For an image, you might depict a bamboo tube with a noticeable bend or twist, alongside a bone that is similarly crooked, symbolizing the deep-seated nature of the person's deceit.

Actual idiom: คนดีผีคุ้ม
Literal Translation: Good people are protected by spirits.
Idiom meaning in English: Good people are not in danger.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คนดีผีคุ้ม" translates to "Good people are protected by spirits." It suggests that virtuous individuals are safeguarded by benevolent forces or spirits. For an image representation, you might depict a kind-hearted person surrounded by gentle, protective spirits or ethereal guardians, symbolizing the idea that their goodness attracts positive, protective energies.

Actual idiom: คนในอยากออก คนนอกอยากเข้า
Literal Translation: People inside want to get out, people outside want to get in.
English Pronounciation: Khon nai yak ok khon nok yak khao
Idiom meaning in English: Dissatisfaction with the current situation, while others want to be in that situation, married people want to be single again, but unmarried people want to have a partner.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "คนในอยากออก คนนอกอยากเข้า" translates to "Those inside want to get out, those outside want to get in." This saying reflects the human tendency to desire what one does not have, often leading to a lack of contentment with one's current situation. It highlights the grass-is-always-greener mentality, where people on the inside of a situation or group may feel trapped or dissatisfied, while those on the outside view it as desirable and aspire to be part of it. 

For an image representation, you might depict a scene with two groups of people separated by a fence or barrier. The people inside the fence look longingly outward, while those outside the fence gaze enviously inward. This visual contrast captures the essence of the idiom, illustrating the mutual desire to switch places.

Actual idiom: คนรักเท่าผืนหนัง คนชังเท่าผืนเสื่อ
Literal Translation: People who love are as big as a piece of skin, people who hate are as big as a mat.
English Pronounciation: Khon rak thao phuen nang khon chang thao phuen suea
Idiom meaning in English: There are few people who love you, and many people who hate you.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "คนรักเท่าผืนหนัง คนชังเท่าผืนเสื่อ" translates to "Those who love you are as few as a piece of leather, those who hate you are as many as a mat." This idiom suggests that genuine love and affection from others are rare and precious, like a small piece of leather, while hatred and animosity are abundant and widespread, like a large mat. It highlights the idea that true friends and supporters are few, whereas critics and adversaries are many. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a small, valuable piece of leather contrasted with a large, common mat, symbolizing the scarcity of true love and the abundance of hatred.

Actual idiom: คนละไม้คนละมือ
English Pronounciation: Khon la mai khon la mue
Idiom meaning in English: Everyone helps each other.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คนละไม้คนละมือ" translates to "each person with a different piece of wood, each person with a different hand." It means that everyone contributes in their own way to achieve a common goal. The image could depict a group of people working together, each holding a different tool or piece of material, symbolizing their unique contributions to a collective effort.

Actual idiom: คบคนจรนอนหมอนหมิ่น
Literal Translation: Hang out with a vagabond and sleep with a pillow that is despicable.
English Pronounciation: Khop khon chon non mon min
Idiom meaning in English: Having a vague relationship can be harmful, just like sleeping on an inappropriate pillow can cause a stiff neck.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คบคนจรนอนหมอนหมิ่น" translates to "Befriending a wanderer, you sleep on a low pillow." It means that associating with unreliable or transient people can lead to discomfort or instability in your life. For an image, you might depict a person lying on a thin, uncomfortable pillow, symbolizing the lack of security and comfort that comes from keeping unreliable company.

Actual idiom: คบคนจรหมอนหมิ่น
Literal Translation: Keeping company with vagabonds is despicable.
Idiom meaning in English: Having a vague relationship can be harmful, just like sleeping on an inappropriate pillow can cause a stiff neck.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คบคนจรหมอนหมิ่น" translates to "Associating with a wanderer, your pillow will be thin." It means that if you associate with unreliable or unstable people, you will face discomfort and instability in your own life. For an image, you might depict a person with a thin, worn-out pillow, symbolizing discomfort, alongside a wanderer or a transient figure, indicating the source of the instability.

Actual idiom: คบคนพาล พาลพาไปหาผิด
Literal Translation: Hang out with bad people and they will lead you astray.
English Pronounciation: Khop khon phan phan pha pai ha phit
Idiom meaning in English: The abbreviation of "keeping company with bad people will lead you to wrongdoing; keeping company with wise people will lead you to success."
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คบคนพาล พาลพาไปหาผิด" translates to "If you associate with bad people, they will lead you to wrongdoing." This idiom suggests that the company you keep can influence your behavior and decisions, often leading you astray if you surround yourself with negative influences. An image representing this idiom might depict a person being led down a dark or dangerous path by a group of shady or mischievous characters, symbolizing the negative impact of bad associations.

Actual idiom: คบคนพาล พาลพาไปหาผิด คบบัณฑิต บัณฑิตพาไปหาผล
Literal Translation: Keep company with bad people, bad people will lead you to wrongdoings. Keep company with wise people, wise people will lead you to success.
English Pronounciation: Khop khon phan phan pha pai ha phit khop bandit bandit pha pai ha phon
Idiom meaning in English: Choosing friends must be considered carefully. if you make friends with bad people, bad people will lead you down a bad path. if you make friends with good people who are knowledgeable, good people will lead you down a good path.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "คบคนพาล พาลพาไปหาผิด คบบัณฑิต บัณฑิตพาไปหาผล" translates to "Associate with the wicked, and they will lead you to wrongdoing; associate with the wise, and they will lead you to success." This idiom emphasizes the importance of choosing one's companions wisely, as they can significantly influence one's actions and outcomes in life. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict two contrasting scenes: one showing a person being led astray by a group of mischievous or malevolent individuals, and the other showing a person being guided towards success and prosperity by a group of wise and knowledgeable individuals.

Actual idiom: คบคนให้ดูหน้า ซื้อผ้าให้ดูเนื้อ
Literal Translation: When choosing a friend, look at their face; when buying cloth, look at the texture.
English Pronounciation: Khop khon hai du na sue pha hai du nuea
Idiom meaning in English: Before dating someone, consider carefully. just like when buying clothes, you have to consider the material.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คบคนให้ดูหน้า ซื้อผ้าให้ดูเนื้อ" translates to "When befriending someone, look at their face; when buying cloth, look at its texture." This means that just as you should examine the quality of fabric before purchasing it, you should also carefully consider a person's character and appearance before forming a relationship with them. The idiom emphasizes the importance of discernment and careful judgment in both social interactions and material acquisitions.

Idiom meaning in English: They have knowledge and ability but when the time is not right, they do not show it.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คมในฝัก" (Kom Nai Fak) translates to "sharpness in the sheath" in English. It describes a person who possesses great skill, intelligence, or talent but does not show it openly. The imagery suggests a sharp sword kept in its sheath, symbolizing hidden potential or abilities that are not immediately visible.

Actual idiom: คลื่นกระทบฝั่ง
Idiom meaning in English: Stories that were sensational then faded away
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "คลื่นกระทบฝั่ง" translates to "waves crashing against the shore" in English. This idiom is often used to describe a situation where problems or challenges are inevitable and recurring, much like how waves continuously crash against the shore. It conveys the idea that difficulties are a natural part of life and must be faced and dealt with repeatedly. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a serene beach scene with waves consistently rolling in and breaking upon the shore, symbolizing the ongoing nature of life's challenges.

Actual idiom: คลื่นใต้น้ำ
Idiom meaning in English: The situation is simmering inside but appears peaceful on the outside.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คลื่นใต้น้ำ" translates to "undercurrent" in English. It describes hidden or unseen forces at work beneath the surface, often referring to underlying tensions, conflicts, or movements that are not immediately visible but can have significant impacts. An image representing this idiom might depict a calm sea with subtle, swirling currents beneath the surface, symbolizing the hidden dynamics at play.

Actual idiom: คลื่นลูกใหม่
Idiom meaning in English: A new generation of educated and progressive people are taking over the role of the older generation in various operations.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คลื่นลูกใหม่" translates to "new wave" in English. It symbolizes the emergence of new ideas, trends, or generations that replace the old ones. The imagery often involves a powerful wave in the ocean, representing the unstoppable force of change and innovation that sweeps away the outdated or traditional ways. This idiom highlights the natural progression and evolution within societies, industries, or cultures.

Actual idiom: คลุกคลีตีโมง
Idiom meaning in English: Gather or live together in close contact all the time
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'คลุกคลีตีโมง' translates to "mixing and beating the clock." It describes a situation where someone is deeply involved or entangled in an activity, often to the point of losing track of time. The imagery suggests a person so engrossed in their task that they are metaphorically "beating" the hours away, indicating intense focus or dedication.

Idiom meaning in English: The appearance of both parties meeting each other without ever seeing or knowing each other before is often used in the old-fashioned wedding tradition where parents arrange it, even though the parties have never known or loved each other before.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คลุมถุงชน" (Klum Thung Chon) translates to "covering with a sack and hitting" in English. It refers to an arranged marriage where the individuals involved have little to no say in the matter, often decided by their families. The imagery suggests a lack of personal choice and the feeling of being trapped or forced into a situation without consent.

Idiom meaning in English: By implication, it means a story that has already happened and is resurfacing again.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ควันหลง" (Kwan Long) translates to "lingering smoke" in English. It refers to the remnants or aftereffects of an event, situation, or action, much like how smoke lingers in the air after a fire has been extinguished. The imagery suggests that even after the main event has concluded, its impact or consequences can still be felt or observed.

Actual idiom: คว้าน้ำเหลว
Idiom meaning in English: Did not work as desired
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'คว้าน้ำเหลว' translates to "grasping at water in vain" in English. It describes a situation where someone makes an effort but ends up with nothing to show for it, similar to trying to hold water in your hands and finding it impossible to keep. The image could depict a person attempting to scoop water with their hands, only to have it slip through their fingers, symbolizing futile efforts and unproductive endeavors.

Actual idiom: ความรู้ท่วมหัวเอาตัวไม่รอด
Literal Translation: Overwhelmed with knowledge, one cannot survive.
English Pronounciation: Khwam ru thuam hua ao tua mai rot
Idiom meaning in English: Have a lot of knowledge but don't know how to use it to your advantage.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ความรู้ท่วมหัวเอาตัวไม่รอด" translates to "Knowledge overflows the head but cannot save oneself." It describes a situation where a person may possess a vast amount of knowledge or information, yet lacks the practical skills or wisdom to effectively apply it in real-life situations, leading to failure or inability to cope with challenges. An image representing this idiom could depict a person with an exaggeratedly large head filled with books or symbols of knowledge, struggling or failing to navigate a difficult situation or obstacle.

Actual idiom: ความวัวไม่ทันหาย ความควายเข้ามาแทรก
Literal Translation: Before the problem can be solved, another problem comes along.
English Pronounciation: Khwam wua mai than hai khwam khwai khao ma saek
Idiom meaning in English: There was a problem that had arisen, and before it could be resolved or settled, another problem arose, making it two problems at once.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ความวัวไม่ทันหาย ความควายเข้ามาแทรก" translates to "The problem with the cow isn't resolved yet, and the buffalo problem comes in." It means that before one problem is solved, another problem arises. For an image, you could depict a scene where a person is trying to deal with a troublesome cow, and before they can resolve the issue, a buffalo appears, adding to their troubles. This visual would capture the essence of being overwhelmed by multiple problems at once.

Idiom meaning in English: Refuse to associate with
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'คว่ำบาตร' (pronounced "kwam bat") translates to "turning the alms bowl upside down." It symbolizes a complete rejection or severing of a relationship, often in a social or religious context. The imagery involves a monk's alms bowl, which is used to receive food offerings. Turning it upside down signifies that no more offerings will be accepted, representing a decisive end to any further interaction or support.

Actual idiom: คอขาดบาดตาย
Idiom meaning in English: Serious enough to cause loss of life
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คอขาดบาดตาย" translates to "life and death situation" in English. It describes a scenario of extreme urgency or critical importance, where the stakes are incredibly high, often involving life-threatening consequences. An image representing this idiom could depict a dramatic, intense scene, such as a person standing at the edge of a cliff, a high-stakes medical emergency, or a tense moment in a battlefield, emphasizing the gravity and seriousness of the situation.

Actual idiom: คอทั่งสันหลังเหล็ก
Idiom meaning in English: Strong, resilient
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คอทั่งสันหลังเหล็ก" translates to "an anvil neck and an iron spine" in English. It describes a person who is extremely resilient, strong, and unyielding, both physically and mentally. This individual can withstand great pressure and challenges without breaking down. For an image, you might depict a person with a neck resembling an anvil and a spine made of iron, standing firm and resolute amidst a storm or heavy burden.

Actual idiom: คอเป็นเอ็น
Idiom meaning in English: Raising a voice and arguing relentlessly, being good at arguing
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'คอเป็นเอ็น' translates to "a neck like a tendon" in English. It describes someone who is very stubborn or adamant, often to the point of being inflexible or unyielding. The imagery suggests a person whose neck is so tense and rigid that it resembles a tightly stretched tendon, symbolizing their unwavering stance or determination.

Idiom meaning in English: Likes to cause trouble by going to court
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "ค้าความ" translates to "litigation" or "legal dispute" in English. It often conveys the idea of engaging in legal battles or disputes, typically implying that such actions can be costly, time-consuming, and may not always lead to a satisfactory resolution. The idiom suggests caution against unnecessary legal conflicts and highlights the potential negative consequences of pursuing litigation. 

For an image representation, you might consider depicting a courtroom scene with two parties in conflict, a judge presiding over the case, and perhaps a scale of justice symbolizing the legal process.

Actual idiom: คางคกขึ้นวอ
Idiom meaning in English: People with low status tend to act arrogantly when they become successful and forget themselves.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คางคกขึ้นวอ" (pronounced "khang khok khuen wo") translates to "a toad on a palanquin." It describes a situation where someone who is not accustomed to luxury or high status suddenly finds themselves in such a position and behaves arrogantly or inappropriately. The image would depict a toad being carried on an ornate palanquin, symbolizing the incongruity and the toad's unaccustomed behavior in this elevated situation.

Actual idiom: คางคกขึ้นวอ แมลงปอใส่ตุ้งติ้ง
Literal Translation: Toads climb the wall, dragonflies wear bells
English Pronounciation: Khang khok khuen wo malaeng po sai tung ting
Idiom meaning in English: People with low status tend to act arrogantly when they become successful and forget themselves.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คางคกขึ้นวอ แมลงปอใส่ตุ้งติ้ง" translates to "A toad on a palanquin, a dragonfly wearing earrings." It describes someone who is out of place or trying to appear more important or sophisticated than they really are. The imagery suggests a toad, which is typically seen as lowly or unattractive, being carried in a palanquin, a mode of transport for the elite, and a dragonfly, a simple insect, adorned with earrings, which are unnecessary and extravagant for it. This idiom highlights the absurdity and pretentiousness of such behavior.

Idiom meaning in English: Failed to complete
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ค้างเติ่ง' (khang terng) translates to "left hanging" in English. It describes a situation where something is left incomplete or unresolved, often causing inconvenience or frustration. The imagery could involve an unfinished task, a person waiting indefinitely, or something suspended in mid-air, symbolizing the lack of closure or completion.

Idiom meaning in English: Sick or injured to the point of almost dying, often used as "if you don't die, your chin will be yellow."
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คางเหลือง" (Kang Lueang) translates to "yellow chin" in English. It is used to describe someone who is very young or inexperienced, often implying that they are still naive or immature. The imagery of a "yellow chin" suggests the idea of youthfulness, as if the person is still in the early stages of life or learning.

Actual idiom: คาบช้อนเงินช้อนทองมาเกิด
Literal Translation: Born with a silver spoon in the mouth
English Pronounciation: Khab chon ngoen chon thong ma koet
Idiom meaning in English: Born into a wealthy family
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'คาบช้อนเงินช้อนทองมาเกิด' translates to "born with a silver spoon in one's mouth" in English. It describes someone who is born into wealth and privilege, enjoying advantages and opportunities from birth. For an image, you might depict a baby holding or surrounded by silver and gold spoons, symbolizing their affluent start in life.

Actual idiom: คาบช้อนทองมาเกิด
Literal Translation: Born with a golden spoon in mouth
Idiom meaning in English: Synonyms of born with a silver spoon in mouth
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คาบช้อนทองมาเกิด" translates to "born with a silver spoon in one's mouth" in English. It describes someone who is born into wealth and privilege, enjoying advantages and opportunities from birth without having to work for them. An image representing this idiom might depict a baby holding or surrounded by a golden spoon, symbolizing their affluent beginnings.

Actual idiom: คาบลูกคาบดอก
Idiom meaning in English: Uncertain, ambiguous
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'คาบลูกคาบดอก' (khab luk khab dok) translates to "holding both the fruit and the flower" in English. It describes a situation where someone is caught between two equally important or valuable things, often leading to a dilemma or a challenging decision. The imagery suggests a person trying to balance or manage two precious items simultaneously, highlighting the difficulty and care required in such a situation.

Actual idiom: คาหนังคาเขา
Idiom meaning in English: Caught while committing an offence or with evidence
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คาหนังคาเขา" translates to "caught red-handed" in English. It describes a situation where someone is caught in the act of doing something wrong or illegal, with undeniable evidence. For an image representation, you might depict a person being apprehended while committing a misdeed, such as stealing or cheating, with clear evidence of their wrongdoing visible.

Actual idiom: คาหลังคาเขา
Idiom meaning in English: Caught while committing an offence or with evidence
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'คาหลังคาเขา' translates to 'stuck on someone else's roof' in English. It describes a situation where someone is caught in a difficult or awkward position, often due to meddling in someone else's affairs or being in a place where they don't belong. The imagery suggests being trapped or entangled in a problem that is not one's own, highlighting the consequences of overstepping boundaries.

Idiom meaning in English: There are some things that make you feel compelled to do or refrain from doing.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ค้ำคอ' (pronounced "kham kho") translates to "supporting the neck" in English. It describes a situation where someone is forced to endure or tolerate something unpleasant or burdensome, often due to obligations or lack of alternatives. The imagery suggests a person holding up their neck, symbolizing the strain and discomfort they must bear.

Idiom meaning in English: Revenge, retaliation for what others have done to oneself or one's group.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'คิดบัญชี' (khit banchee) translates to "keeping accounts" or "settling accounts" in English. It metaphorically refers to the act of holding someone accountable for their actions, often implying that there will be consequences or a reckoning for past deeds. The imagery could involve a person meticulously writing in a ledger or a balance scale symbolizing justice and accountability.

Actual idiom: คิดหน้าคิดหลัง
Idiom meaning in English: Think carefully
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คิดหน้าคิดหลัง" translates to "Think ahead, think behind" in English. It emphasizes the importance of careful consideration and planning before taking action. The imagery for this idiom could include a person standing at a crossroads, thoughtfully contemplating their options, or someone holding a map and looking both forward and backward, symbolizing the act of weighing potential outcomes and consequences before making a decision.

Actual idiom: คืบก็ทะเล ศอกก็ทะเล
Literal Translation: cubit is the sea, a cubit is the sea.
English Pronounciation: Khuep ko thale sok ko thale
Idiom meaning in English: When going out to sea, do not be careless with the sea because danger can occur at any time.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คืบก็ทะเล ศอกก็ทะเล" translates to "A span is the sea, an arm's length is the sea." It conveys the idea that even small distances or efforts can seem vast and challenging, much like the sea. This idiom often highlights the perception of difficulty or the enormity of a task, regardless of its actual size. An image representing this idiom might depict a person standing at the edge of a vast ocean, emphasizing the overwhelming nature of the sea compared to the small human figure.

Idiom meaning in English: A man and a woman who are hired to go on a trip or go to an event together, a young couple or a couple who travel alone.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คู่เดต" translates to "a perfect match" or "a couple destined to be together." It refers to two people who complement each other perfectly, often in a romantic context. For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a harmonious couple engaged in a loving or joyful activity, symbolizing their compatibility and mutual affection.

Actual idiom: เคราะห์หามยามร้าย
Idiom meaning in English: Bad luck
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "เคราะห์หามยามร้าย" translates to "misfortune strikes at a bad time" in English. It conveys the idea that bad luck or unfortunate events often occur when one is already in a difficult situation. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a person struggling under a heavy rainstorm while carrying a broken umbrella, symbolizing the compounded difficulties and bad timing of misfortunes.

Actual idiom: เคียงบ่าเคียงไหล่
Idiom meaning in English: Having equal status, being on the same level, sharing happiness and sorrow, or sharing life and death together.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'เคียงบ่าเคียงไหล่' translates to 'shoulder to shoulder' in English. It describes a situation where people stand together in unity, support, and solidarity, often working together towards a common goal or facing challenges side by side. The imagery evokes a sense of camaraderie, mutual support, and close cooperation.

Actual idiom: เคราะห์ซ้ำกรรมซัด
Idiom meaning in English: The original bad luck is already severe and there is another bad luck on top of it, suffering bad luck over and over again.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เคราะห์ซ้ำกรรมซัด" translates to "misfortunes never come singly" or "when it rains, it pours." It describes a situation where multiple bad events or misfortunes happen simultaneously or in quick succession, compounding the difficulty and distress. An image to represent this idiom might include a person struggling against a storm with dark clouds, heavy rain, and strong winds, symbolizing the overwhelming nature of consecutive troubles.

Actual idiom: โคแก่ชอบกินหญ้าอ่อน
Literal Translation: Old cows like to eat young grass.
English Pronounciation: Kho kae chop kin ya on
Idiom meaning in English: An older man who likes younger women
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'โคแก่ชอบกินหญ้าอ่อน' translates to 'An old cow likes to eat young grass' in English. This idiom is used to describe an older person who is romantically interested in someone much younger. The imagery involves an old cow preferring tender, young grass over mature grass, symbolizing the attraction of an older individual to youthful partners.

Actual idiom: โค้งสุดท้าย
Idiom meaning in English: The final moments of a competition before the winner is determined
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'โค้งสุดท้าย' translates to 'the final curve' in English. It refers to the critical last phase of an endeavor, where the outcome is about to be determined. This stage is crucial and often requires maximum effort and focus to achieve success. An image representing this idiom might depict a race track with runners or vehicles approaching the final bend, symbolizing the urgency and importance of this concluding segment.

Actual idiom: ฆ้องปากแตก
Idiom meaning in English: A big mouth, a person who can't keep a secret, a person who likes to tell other people's secrets, a person who can't keep a secret
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ฆ้องปากแตก" translates to "a broken-mouthed gong" in English. It describes a person who cannot keep a secret and tends to gossip or spread information indiscriminately. The imagery of a gong with a broken mouth suggests that just as a damaged gong cannot produce a clear, controlled sound, a person who is a "broken-mouthed gong" cannot control their speech and leaks information carelessly.

Actual idiom: ฆ่าควายเสียดายเกลือ
Literal Translation: Killing a buffalo is a waste of salt.
Idiom meaning in English: When undertaking big projects, one should not be stingy.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "ฆ่าควายเสียดายเกลือ" translates to "Killing a buffalo but regretting the salt." It means that someone is willing to make a significant sacrifice or take a major action but then hesitates or regrets over a minor detail or small cost. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a large, strong buffalo being sacrificed, with a person nearby looking regretful or concerned about a small amount of salt. The contrast between the large buffalo and the small quantity of salt should be emphasized to highlight the irony and the message of the idiom.

Actual idiom: ฆ่าควายอย่าเสียดายพริก
Literal Translation: Kill a buffalo, don't be stingy with chilies.
Idiom meaning in English: When undertaking big projects, one should not be stingy.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ฆ่าควายอย่าเสียดายพริก" translates to "When killing a buffalo, don't be stingy with the chili." It means that when undertaking a significant task or making a substantial investment, one should not be overly frugal with minor expenses. The imagery involves a large buffalo and the relatively small amount of chili, suggesting that in the context of a major effort, small additional costs should not be a concern.

Actual idiom: ฆ่าช้างเอางา
Literal Translation: Killing elephants to take their tusks
Idiom meaning in English: Destroying big things to get small things that aren't worth it.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ฆ่าช้างเอางา" translates to "killing an elephant for its tusks." It describes a situation where someone takes extreme or destructive measures to obtain something valuable, often implying that the action is excessive and wasteful. The imagery involves an elephant, symbolizing something grand and significant, being killed solely for its tusks, which are valuable but not worth the loss of the entire elephant.

Actual idiom: ฆ่าไม่ตายขายไม่ขาด
English Pronounciation: Kha mai tai khai mai khat
Idiom meaning in English: Can't cut the ties (often used for parents who love their children very much, no matter how angry or hate them, they can't cut them off)
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ฆ่าไม่ตายขายไม่ขาด" translates to "Cannot be killed, cannot be sold off." It describes a situation or a person that is resilient and enduring, no matter how much effort is put into getting rid of them or it. The imagery for this idiom could include an indestructible object or a persistent person who remains steadfast despite numerous attempts to eliminate or separate from them.

Actual idiom: งงเป็นไก่ตาแตก
Literal Translation: I'm so confused I'm going blind.
Idiom meaning in English: I'm so confused that i don't know what to do.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "งงเป็นไก่ตาแตก" translates to "confused like a chicken with shattered eyes." It describes a state of extreme confusion or bewilderment, akin to a chicken that is disoriented and frantic. For an image, you might depict a chicken with wide, bewildered eyes, possibly surrounded by chaotic or confusing elements to emphasize its disoriented state.

Idiom meaning in English: Those who go everywhere together are almost never separated.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เงาตามตัว" translates to "a shadow following the body" in English. It signifies something or someone that is always present or inseparable, much like a shadow that constantly follows a person. This can be used to describe a loyal companion, an inescapable consequence, or an ever-present aspect of one's life. For an image, you might depict a person walking with a distinct shadow closely mirroring their every move, emphasizing the idea of constant presence and inseparability.

Actual idiom: เงื้อง่าราคาแพง
Idiom meaning in English: No matter what i do, i don't dare to make a decision. i only act or pretend that i will do it.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เงื้อง่าราคาแพง" translates to "raising one's hand is expensive." It means that taking action or making a decision can come with significant costs or consequences. For an image representation, you might depict a person hesitating to raise their hand, with a backdrop suggesting high stakes or potential costs, such as a scale with money or a complex situation.

Actual idiom: งมเข็มในมหาสมุทร
Literal Translation: Finding a Needle in the Ocean
Idiom meaning in English: Find the hard to find, do the hard to accomplish
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "งมเข็มในมหาสมุทร" translates to "searching for a needle in the ocean" in English. It describes a task that is extremely difficult or nearly impossible to accomplish due to the vastness and complexity of the situation. The imagery involves a person trying to find a tiny needle in the vast expanse of the ocean, highlighting the improbability and the immense challenge of the endeavor.

Idiom meaning in English: There was complete suffering.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'งอมพระราม' (ngom phra ram) translates to "exhausted like Rama." It refers to being extremely tired or worn out, often after a long and arduous effort. The imagery could depict a person who is visibly fatigued, perhaps with drooping shoulders, heavy eyelids, and a weary expression, symbolizing the exhaustion and struggle akin to the trials faced by the character Rama in the Ramayana epic.

Actual idiom: งอมืองอตีน
Idiom meaning in English: Lazy, not interested in working, not thinking of fighting
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'งอมืองอตีน' translates to "folding one's arms and legs" in English. It describes a person who is being lazy or inactive, not making any effort to work or contribute. The imagery suggests someone sitting idly with their arms and legs bent, doing nothing productive.

Actual idiom: ง่อยเปลี้ยเสียขา
Idiom meaning in English: Has a physical disability that makes him unable to walk normally.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ง่อยเปลี้ยเสียขา" translates to "crippled and losing a leg" in English. It is used metaphorically to describe someone who is severely disadvantaged, incapacitated, or unable to function effectively due to significant obstacles or limitations. The imagery for this idiom could depict a person struggling to move forward, possibly with crutches or a missing limb, symbolizing their struggle and the challenges they face.

Actual idiom: งานหนักไม่เอา งานเบาไม่สู้
Literal Translation: I don't want hard work, I don't want easy work.
English Pronounciation: Ngan nak mai ao ngan bao mai su
Idiom meaning in English: No patience to do work
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "งานหนักไม่เอา งานเบาไม่สู้" translates to "Won't take on hard work, won't fight for easy work." It describes a person who avoids difficult tasks but also does not put effort into simpler tasks, implying a lack of diligence or willingness to work. For an image representation, you might depict a person sitting idly between two tasks, one appearing challenging and the other easy, showing reluctance towards both.

Actual idiom: งานหลวงไม่ขาด งานราษฎร์ไม่เสีย
Literal Translation: Royal work is not neglected, people's work is not lost.
English Pronounciation: Ngan luang mai khat ngan rat mai sia
Idiom meaning in English: Work without fail in both public and private work.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "งานหลวงไม่ขาด งานราษฎร์ไม่เสีย" translates to "Public duties are not neglected, and private affairs are not harmed." It emphasizes the importance of balancing one's responsibilities to the public or community with personal or private obligations. An image representing this idiom could depict a person skillfully juggling or balancing two sets of tasks or responsibilities, symbolizing the harmony between public service and personal life.

Actual idiom: งานหลวงไม่ให้ขาด งานราษฎร์ไม่ให้เสีย
Literal Translation: Do not neglect royal duties, and do not neglect public duties.
English Pronounciation: Ngan luang mai hai khat ngan rat mai hai sia
Idiom meaning in English: Work without fail in both public and private work.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "งานหลวงไม่ให้ขาด งานราษฎร์ไม่ให้เสีย" translates to "Do not neglect public duties, do not let private duties suffer." It emphasizes the importance of balancing responsibilities to both public and private affairs, ensuring that neither is neglected or compromised. An image representing this idiom might depict a person skillfully juggling or balancing two sets of tasks or responsibilities, symbolizing the harmony between public and private obligations.

Actual idiom: งู ๆ ปลา ๆ
Literal Translation: A little bit of a snake
Idiom meaning in English: Have a little knowledge, don't really know
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'งู ๆ ปลา ๆ' (pronounced "ngoo ngoo plaa plaa") translates to "snake snake, fish fish" in English. It describes a situation where someone has only a superficial or rudimentary understanding of a subject, akin to knowing just enough to get by but not truly mastering it. For an image representation, you might depict a person attempting to study or engage in an activity with minimal knowledge, perhaps surrounded by simple drawings or symbols of snakes and fish to emphasize the basic and incomplete nature of their understanding.

Idiom meaning in English: Interconnected in many ways
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "งูกินหาง" (ngoo gin haang) translates to "a snake eating its own tail." This idiom symbolizes a situation where someone is caught in a self-destructive cycle or a problem that perpetuates itself. It can also represent a situation where actions are futile and lead to no progress, much like a snake endlessly chasing its own tail.

Actual idiom: งูเงี้ยวเขี้ยวขอ
Idiom meaning in English: Snakes or various poisonous animals, figuratively meaning a warning from adults not to go anywhere at night.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'งูเงี้ยวเขี้ยวขอ' (ngu ngieow khieow kho) translates to "snakes and fangs" in English. It is used to describe people who are deceitful, dangerous, or treacherous, much like venomous snakes. The imagery suggests hidden threats and the need to be cautious of those who may appear harmless but have harmful intentions.

Actual idiom: เงยหน้าอ้าปาก
Idiom meaning in English: Has a better financial status than before, comparable to friends.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เงยหน้าอ้าปาก" (ngoi naa aa paak) translates to "lift your face and open your mouth." It symbolizes a situation where someone is finally able to improve their circumstances or achieve a better standard of living after a period of hardship. The imagery suggests a person who has been struggling but is now able to look up and speak out, indicating newfound confidence and opportunity.

Actual idiom: เงียบเป็นเป่าสาก
Idiom meaning in English: Silent feature
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เงียบเป็นเป่าสาก" translates to "silent as blowing a pestle." It describes a situation where someone is extremely quiet or unresponsive, similar to the futile act of trying to blow a heavy, solid object like a pestle. The imagery suggests an absolute stillness or lack of reaction, emphasizing the depth of the silence.

Idiom meaning in English: The overwhelming power will not be able to escape.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เงื้อมมือ" (Ngeuam Mue) translates to "the reach of a hand" in English. It metaphorically refers to the extent of one's power or influence. To generate an image based on this idiom, you might depict a hand reaching out, symbolizing the ability to extend one's control or impact over a situation or others. The image could include elements that represent authority or influence, such as a hand reaching over a group of people, objects, or a landscape, emphasizing the concept of reach and power.

Actual idiom: โง่แกมหยิ่ง
Idiom meaning in English: Stupid but still pretends to be smart, arrogant even though he is stupid
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'โง่แกมหยิ่ง' translates to "foolish and arrogant" in English. It describes a person who is not only lacking in wisdom or intelligence but also exhibits a sense of unwarranted pride or arrogance. This combination often leads to poor decisions and an inability to recognize or admit one's own mistakes. For an image representation, you might depict a person with a smug expression, perhaps making a blunder or ignoring advice, symbolizing both their foolishness and arrogance.

Actual idiom: โง่แล้วอยากนอนเตียง
Literal Translation: I'm stupid and want to sleep in bed.
Idiom meaning in English: Stupid and not knowing how to be stupid, doing things that one does not know or understand, not being capable but still trying to do things that are not worthy of one's status (often followed by a tilted neck and wanting to prop one's head up with a pillow)
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'โง่แล้วอยากนอนเตียง' translates to 'Foolish but wants to sleep on a bed.' It describes someone who lacks wisdom or capability but desires comfort or luxury beyond their means or merit. The imagery for this idiom could include a person who appears unwise or inexperienced, yet is attempting to rest on an opulent or luxurious bed, symbolizing their unrealistic aspirations.

Actual idiom: เจ้าหน้าเจ้าตา
Idiom meaning in English: Show-off, a person who likes to offer to do business for others without being asked.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เจ้าหน้าเจ้าตา" translates to "a person who is well-known or prominent in society." It describes someone who is frequently seen and recognized in social circles or public events, often due to their status, influence, or active participation in community activities. An image representing this idiom might depict a well-dressed individual at a social gathering, surrounded by people who acknowledge and greet them warmly.

Idiom meaning in English: A lot
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "จนตัวสั่น" translates to "so poor that one trembles." It describes a state of extreme poverty where a person is so destitute that they physically shake from the lack of resources, such as food or warmth. An image representing this idiom might depict a person in tattered clothing, shivering in the cold, with a look of desperation and hunger. The background could show a bleak, barren environment to emphasize the severity of their situation.

Idiom meaning in English: Stuck, not progressing
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "จมปลัก" (pronounced "jom plak") translates to "stuck in the mud" in English. It describes a situation where someone is unable to move forward or make progress, often due to being bogged down by difficulties, bad habits, or negative circumstances. The imagery evokes a person or animal trapped in a muddy pit, struggling to free themselves but unable to do so.

Idiom meaning in English: Once you have made a big thing, you cannot make it smaller (usually used for people who were previously rich or prosperous. when they are poor or in a slump, they still act the same way)
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'จมไม่ลง' (pronounced "jom mai long") translates to "unable to sink" in English. It describes a person who refuses to accept defeat or failure, often out of pride or stubbornness. The imagery could involve a person floating on water, struggling to stay afloat despite the weight pulling them down, symbolizing their refusal to give in or acknowledge their shortcomings.

Idiom meaning in English: Who is aware of or aware of the situation?
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "จมูกมด" (pronounced "ja-mook mod") translates to "ant's nose" in English. It is used to describe someone who is very perceptive or has a keen sense of smell, much like an ant that can detect even the smallest traces of food. In a visual representation, you might depict an ant with an exaggeratedly large nose, perhaps sniffing out something hidden or small, to symbolize this heightened sense of perception.

Actual idiom: จองหองพองขน
Idiom meaning in English: Arrogant and disrespectful to those who have merit
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'จองหองพองขน' translates to "arrogant and puffed up" in English. It describes someone who is excessively proud, boastful, or conceited, often to the point of being disdainful or dismissive of others. The imagery suggests a person who metaphorically puffs up their feathers, like a bird, to appear more important or impressive than they truly are.

Actual idiom: จับงูข้างหาง
Literal Translation: Catch the snake by its tail
Idiom meaning in English: Do something risky
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "จับงูข้างหาง" translates to "catching a snake by its tail" in English. It describes a situation where someone is taking a risky or dangerous action without proper caution, akin to grabbing a snake by its tail, which can easily lead to being bitten. The imagery for this idiom would involve a person holding the tail of a snake, with the snake poised to strike, symbolizing the imminent danger and recklessness of the action.

Actual idiom: จับดำถลำแดง
Literal Translation: Catch the black and fall into the red
Idiom meaning in English: Focus on one thing and get another, focus on one thing and get another
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "จับดำถลำแดง" translates to "catching black, slipping into red." It describes a situation where someone tries to solve a problem or avoid trouble but ends up in an even worse situation. The imagery involves attempting to grasp something dark (a problem) and inadvertently falling into something more severe (a bigger problem). This idiom highlights the unintended consequences of actions and the potential for efforts to backfire.

Actual idiom: จับได้คาหนังคาเขา
English Pronounciation: Chap dai kha nang kha khao
Idiom meaning in English: Caught while committing an offence or with evidence
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "จับได้คาหนังคาเขา" translates to "caught red-handed" in English. It describes a situation where someone is caught in the act of doing something wrong or illegal, with undeniable evidence. For an image representation, you might depict a person being caught in the middle of committing a misdeed, such as stealing or cheating, with clear evidence of their wrongdoing visible.

Actual idiom: จับได้ไล่ทัน
Idiom meaning in English: Speak to trap them into submission, speak to corner them
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "จับได้ไล่ทัน" translates to "caught up with and overtaken" in English. It describes a situation where someone is able to catch up with and surpass another, often in the context of competition or pursuit. The imagery could involve a race or chase where one person is initially behind but manages to close the gap and overtake the leader.

Actual idiom: จับต้นชนปลาย
Idiom meaning in English: Find the cause or origin to piece together the story.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'จับต้นชนปลาย' translates to "grasping the beginning and the end." It describes a situation where someone is trying to make sense of a confusing or complicated matter by understanding its starting point and conclusion. The imagery could involve a person holding the ends of a tangled thread or rope, symbolizing the effort to untangle and comprehend a complex issue.

Actual idiom: จับปลาสองมือ
Idiom meaning in English: Focus on doing two things at the same time
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "จับปลาสองมือ" translates to "catching fish with two hands" in English. It describes a situation where someone is trying to do two things at once, often leading to failure in both tasks. The imagery involves a person attempting to catch fish with both hands simultaneously, which usually results in losing both fish. This idiom highlights the difficulty and inefficiency of multitasking.

Actual idiom: จับปูใส่กระด้ง
Literal Translation: Catch crabs and put them in a basket
Idiom meaning in English: Son is restless.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "จับปูใส่กระด้ง" translates to "catching crabs and putting them in a bamboo basket." It describes a situation where someone is trying to manage or control a chaotic and difficult situation, similar to how crabs would scatter and be hard to contain in a basket. The imagery involves a person struggling to keep multiple crabs from escaping a shallow, round bamboo container, symbolizing the challenge of managing unruly or uncontrollable elements.

Actual idiom: จับพลัดจับผลู
Idiom meaning in English: Accidentally, accidentally
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "จับพลัดจับผลู" (pronounced "jap phlat jap phlu") translates to "by chance" or "by accident" in English. It describes a situation where something happens unexpectedly or coincidentally, often leading to an unforeseen outcome. For an image representation, you might depict a person stumbling upon a treasure chest or finding something valuable by accident, symbolizing the element of surprise and luck.

Actual idiom: จับแพะชนแกะ
Idiom meaning in English: Do things half-heartedly. if you can't do this, do that instead to get it done.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "จับแพะชนแกะ" translates to "catching a goat to collide with a sheep." It describes a situation where someone tries to solve a problem or manage a situation by using whatever resources are available, often in a haphazard or makeshift manner. The imagery suggests a lack of proper planning or organization, leading to a chaotic or ineffective solution.

Actual idiom: จับเสือมือเปล่า
Idiom meaning in English: Seek benefits by yourself without investment
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "จับเสือมือเปล่า" translates to "catching a tiger with bare hands" in English. It describes a situation where someone achieves something difficult or dangerous without any tools or assistance, relying solely on their own skill and bravery. The imagery involves a person confronting a fierce tiger with nothing but their bare hands, symbolizing courage, resourcefulness, and the ability to overcome formidable challenges through sheer determination.

Actual idiom: จุดไต้ตำตอ
Idiom meaning in English: Saying or doing something accidentally affects the person or the owner of the matter without the speaker or doer knowing.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "จุดไต้ตำตอ" (pronounced "jut tai tam tor") translates to "lighting a fire under a stump." It means inadvertently revealing a secret or sensitive information in the presence of someone directly involved or affected by it. The imagery involves someone lighting a fire under a tree stump, not realizing that the stump is still connected to the roots, symbolizing the unintended exposure of hidden truths.

Idiom meaning in English: If an investigation finds out that the perpetrator is an influential person, then the case cannot proceed.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เจอตอ" (pronounced "jer tor") translates to "hit a stump" in English. It is used to describe encountering an unexpected obstacle or difficulty that halts progress. The imagery involves a boat or vehicle moving smoothly until it suddenly hits a submerged tree stump, causing an abrupt stop. This idiom conveys the idea of facing an unforeseen challenge that disrupts plans or efforts.

Actual idiom: เจ้าไม่มีศาล สมภารไม่มีวัด
Literal Translation: You have no court, the abbot has no temple.
English Pronounciation: Chao mai mi san somphan mai mi wat
Idiom meaning in English: People who have no fixed address
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เจ้าไม่มีศาล สมภารไม่มีวัด" translates to "A lord without a court, an abbot without a temple." It describes a situation where someone holds a title or position but lacks the necessary resources, authority, or place to exercise their role effectively. For an image representation, you might depict a noble figure standing alone without a palace or a monk without a temple, symbolizing their lack of a proper domain or means to fulfill their duties.

Actual idiom: เจาะไข่แดง
Idiom meaning in English: Destroying the purity of women
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เจาะไข่แดง" (pronounced "joh khai daeng") translates to "piercing the egg yolk" in English. It is often used to describe getting to the core or the most important part of a matter. In a visual representation, you might depict an egg with its yolk prominently displayed, perhaps with a tool or object piercing through to emphasize the action of reaching the center or the essence of something.

Actual idiom: แจงสี่เบี้ย
Idiom meaning in English: Explain clearly and thoroughly
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "แจงสี่เบี้ย" translates to "explaining four cowries" in English. It refers to a situation where someone is explaining or justifying something in great detail, often to the point of over-explaining or making excuses. The imagery for this idiom could include a person meticulously counting or arranging four cowrie shells, symbolizing the act of detailed explanation or justification.

Actual idiom: โจรห้าร้อย
Idiom meaning in English: Thieves, rascals
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "โจรห้าร้อย" (pronounced "jon ha roi") translates to "five hundred thieves" in English. It is used to describe a situation where there are numerous wrongdoers or a large group of people involved in dishonest or criminal activities. The imagery for this idiom could include a scene with many shadowy figures or thieves, perhaps in a chaotic or secretive setting, to convey the idea of widespread wrongdoing.

Idiom meaning in English: Selfish, uncaring, unkind
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ใจดำ" (pronounced "jai dam") translates to "black-hearted" in English. It describes a person who is cruel, unkind, or lacking in compassion. The imagery associated with this idiom often involves a heart that is dark or black, symbolizing the absence of warmth, kindness, or empathy.

Actual idiom: ใจใหญ่ใจโต
Idiom meaning in English: Think of generosity
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ใจใหญ่ใจโต' translates to "big-hearted" or "generous" in English. It describes a person who is very generous, kind, and willing to help others without expecting anything in return. This person is often seen as magnanimous, with a heart that is metaphorically large, symbolizing their capacity for kindness and generosity. An image representing this idiom might depict a person with an oversized heart, radiating warmth and kindness, perhaps helping others or sharing resources generously.

Actual idiom: ชงเองกินเอง
Literal Translation: Brew it yourself and drink it yourself.
Idiom meaning in English: Doing everything from start to finish for one's own benefit (often used in a reproachful manner)
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ชงเองกินเอง" translates to "Brew it yourself, drink it yourself" in English. It conveys the idea that one must face the consequences of their own actions. For an image representation, you could depict a person preparing a drink and then consuming it, symbolizing the act of dealing with the results of one's own decisions or efforts.

Actual idiom: เชื้อไม่ทิ้งแถว
Literal Translation: The virus does not leave its mark.
Idiom meaning in English: No matter what the parents are like, the children will behave like their parents.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เชื้อไม่ทิ้งแถว" translates to "The seed does not fall far from the tree" in English. It means that children often inherit characteristics, behaviors, or talents from their parents. For an image, you could depict a tree with seeds or fruits falling close to its base, symbolizing the close resemblance or continuity between generations.

Actual idiom: แช่งชักหักกระดูก
Idiom meaning in English: Curse and cause serious harm to others.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "แช่งชักหักกระดูก" translates to "a curse that breaks bones" in English. It conveys the idea of wishing severe harm or misfortune upon someone, often out of intense anger or resentment. The imagery suggests a powerful and destructive curse that goes beyond mere words, implying physical damage or extreme suffering.

Actual idiom: ชนักติดหลัง
Idiom meaning in English: The evil or wrongdoing that still lingers
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ชนักติดหลัง" translates to "a spear stuck in one's back" in English. It metaphorically describes a situation where someone is burdened by a past mistake or wrongdoing that continues to affect them. The imagery involves a person with a spear lodged in their back, symbolizing the lingering consequences or guilt that they cannot easily escape from.

Actual idiom: ชักซุงตามขวาง
Idiom meaning in English: Doing something improperly will bring trouble, obstructing those in power will bring trouble.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ชักซุงตามขวาง' translates to "pulling a log sideways." It describes a situation where someone is attempting to do something in a difficult or inefficient manner, akin to trying to drag a large log sideways instead of lengthwise, which would be much easier. The imagery suggests unnecessary struggle and lack of proper planning or technique.

Idiom meaning in English: Refuse to pay
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ชักดาบ' (pronounced "chak daab") translates to "drawing a sword" in English. It is used metaphorically to describe someone who refuses to pay a debt or avoids paying for something they owe. The imagery involves a person pulling out a sword, symbolizing a bold or defiant action, in this case, the act of not fulfilling a financial obligation.

Actual idiom: ชักดิ้นชักงอ
Idiom meaning in English: Showing anger and dissatisfaction at not getting what one wants
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ชักดิ้นชักงอ" translates to "thrashing about" in English. It describes someone who is reacting very dramatically, often in a fit of anger, frustration, or distress. The imagery suggests a person flailing their limbs wildly, much like a child throwing a tantrum or someone in extreme agitation.

Actual idiom: ชักน้ำเข้าลึก ชักศึกเข้าบ้าน
Literal Translation: Bringing water deep, bringing war into the house
English Pronounciation: Chak nam khao luek chak suek khao ban
Idiom meaning in English: Bring the enemy into your home
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "ชักน้ำเข้าลึก ชักศึกเข้าบ้าน" translates to "Drawing water deep, bringing conflict home." It means that by trying to gain something beneficial or advantageous, one might inadvertently invite trouble or conflict into their own life or household. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a person drawing water from a deep well, with a shadowy figure or a symbol of conflict (like a storm cloud or a menacing figure) approaching their home in the background. This visual would illustrate the unintended consequences of their actions.

Actual idiom: ชักใบให้เรือเสีย
Literal Translation: Raise the sails and spoil the boat
Idiom meaning in English: Saying or doing things in a way that distracts the conversation or work from the subject.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ชักใบให้เรือเสีย' translates to "hoisting the sail to ruin the boat." It describes a situation where someone's actions, intended to help or improve a situation, actually make things worse. The imagery involves a boat where raising the sail improperly or at the wrong time causes it to become unmanageable or leads to its downfall. This idiom is often used to caution against well-meaning but misguided efforts that result in negative consequences.

Idiom meaning in English: Mastermind behind the scenes
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ชักใย' (pronounced "chak yai") translates to "pulling the strings" in English. It refers to someone who is manipulating or controlling a situation or people behind the scenes, much like a puppeteer controls a puppet. The imagery often involves a person covertly influencing events or decisions without being directly visible or acknowledged.

Actual idiom: ชักหน้าไม่ถึงหลัง
Idiom meaning in English: Income is not enough to cover expenses
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ชักหน้าไม่ถึงหลัง" translates to "pulling the front but not reaching the back." It describes a situation where someone is struggling to make ends meet, often financially, indicating that their resources are insufficient to cover all their needs. An image to represent this idiom could depict a person trying to stretch a blanket that is too small to cover both their head and feet, symbolizing the struggle to cover all expenses or needs with limited resources.

Actual idiom: ชั่วช่างชี ดีช่างสงฆ์
Literal Translation: The bad are the monks, the good are the monks.
English Pronounciation: Chua chang chi di chang song
Idiom meaning in English: Let things go as they are, don't make it your business.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ชั่วช่างชี ดีช่างสงฆ์" translates to "Let the bad be the nun's concern, let the good be the monk's concern." It suggests that people should focus on their own responsibilities and not meddle in others' affairs, especially when it comes to moral judgments. An image representing this idiom could depict a serene scene with a nun and a monk, each engaged in their own activities, symbolizing the separation of duties and the importance of minding one's own business.

Actual idiom: ชั่วนาตาปี
Idiom meaning in English: Forever, for many years
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ชั่วนาตาปี' (pronounced "chua naa taa bpee") translates to "for a very long time" or "for eternity." It conveys the idea of something lasting indefinitely or for an extremely long period. In visual terms, this could be represented by an image of an ancient, enduring natural landscape, such as a vast, unchanging mountain range or an old, sturdy tree that has weathered countless seasons, symbolizing timelessness and permanence.

Actual idiom: ช้า ๆ ได้พร้าเล่มงาม
Literal Translation: Slow and steady wins the race.
English Pronounciation: Cha cha dai phra lem ngam
Idiom meaning in English: Think slowly, act slowly, and you will succeed.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ช้า ๆ ได้พร้าเล่มงาม" translates to "Slowly, you get a beautiful knife." It means that taking your time and being patient will yield better results. The imagery involves a person carefully crafting or selecting a fine, beautiful knife, symbolizing the value of patience and meticulous effort.

Actual idiom: ช้า ๆ ได้พร้าสองเล่มงาม
Literal Translation: Slow and steady wins the race.
English Pronounciation: Cha cha dai phra song lem ngam
Idiom meaning in English: Think slowly, act slowly, and you will succeed.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ช้า ๆ ได้พร้าสองเล่มงาม" translates to "Slowly, you get two beautiful machetes." It means that taking your time and being patient can lead to better results. The imagery involves a person carefully crafting or acquiring two finely made machetes, symbolizing the rewards of patience and meticulous effort.

Actual idiom: ช้างตายทั้งตัวเอาใบบัวมาปิด
Literal Translation: A dead elephant is covered with lotus leaves.
English Pronounciation: Chang tai thang tua ao bai bua ma pit
Idiom meaning in English: Serious evil or wrongdoing that is widely known cannot be concealed no matter how much you cover it up.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ช้างตายทั้งตัวเอาใบบัวมาปิด" translates to "Covering a dead elephant with a lotus leaf." It means trying to hide something very large or significant with an inadequate or trivial cover-up. The image would depict a large elephant lying down, with a small lotus leaf placed on it, symbolizing the futility of trying to conceal something so obvious.

Idiom meaning in English: The powerful
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ช้างสาร" (Chang San) translates to "elephant" in English. In Thai culture, elephants are often symbols of strength, power, and wisdom. The idiom typically refers to something or someone that is large, powerful, and influential. For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a majestic, strong elephant standing tall, possibly in a natural setting like a forest or near a river, symbolizing its grandeur and significance.

Actual idiom: ชาติหน้าตอนบ่าย ๆ
Idiom meaning in English: A future time that will never come, impossible (compare english "when pigs fly.")
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ชาติหน้าตอนบ่าย ๆ" translates to "in the next life, in the afternoon." It is used to express the idea that something is highly unlikely to happen or will never happen. The imagery suggests a distant, almost impossible future event, emphasizing the improbability of the situation. For an image, you might depict a serene, timeless scene with a clock showing the afternoon hours, perhaps with ethereal or dreamlike elements to convey the sense of an unattainable future.

Actual idiom: ช้าเป็นการ นานเป็นคุณ
Literal Translation: Slow is good, long is good.
English Pronounciation: Cha pen kan nan pen khun
Idiom meaning in English: Think slowly and do slowly, it's better than doing it quickly.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ช้าเป็นการ นานเป็นคุณ" translates to "Slow is a process, long is a benefit" in English. It emphasizes the value of patience and taking one's time to ensure quality and thoroughness. The idiom suggests that rushing through tasks can lead to mistakes, while taking the time to do things properly will yield better results in the long run. An image representing this idiom might include a person carefully crafting something with attention to detail, or a scene where nature grows and flourishes over time, symbolizing the benefits of patience and diligence.

Actual idiom: ชายสามโบสถ์
Idiom meaning in English: A person who has been ordained and disrobed three times is used to express reproach, saying that he is not someone worth associating with.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ชายสามโบสถ์" translates to "a man of three temples" in English. It describes a man who has been married three times, often implying that he is unreliable or unfaithful in relationships. The imagery for this idiom could include a man standing at the intersection of three different temples, each representing a past marriage, with a contemplative or regretful expression. The background could show the distinct architectural styles of traditional Thai temples to emphasize the cultural context.

Actual idiom: ชายหาบหญิงคอน
Idiom meaning in English: Both husband and wife help each other earn a living.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ชายหาบหญิงคอน" translates to "Men carry on their shoulders, women carry on their heads." This idiom reflects traditional gender roles in Thai society, where men and women have distinct but complementary responsibilities. Men are often seen as the primary breadwinners, taking on physically demanding tasks, while women manage household duties and other responsibilities. An image representing this idiom could depict a man carrying a heavy load on his shoulders and a woman balancing a basket or container on her head, symbolizing their respective roles and contributions.

Actual idiom: ชิงนรกเกิด
Idiom meaning in English: Very bad (like a hellish animal)
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ชิงนรกเกิด" translates to "competing to be born in hell." It describes a situation where people are fiercely competing or engaging in unethical behavior, leading to negative consequences or moral downfall. The imagery for this idiom could include individuals in a heated competition, with dark, fiery, or hellish elements in the background to symbolize the dire consequences of their actions.

Actual idiom: ชิงสุกก่อนห่าม
Idiom meaning in English: Doing something that is not appropriate for one's age or time (usually referring to having sex before marriage), used as a teaching or warning not to be hasty.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ชิงสุกก่อนห่าม" translates to "to pluck the fruit before it is ripe." It means to act prematurely or to rush into something before the appropriate time, often leading to unfavorable outcomes. An image representing this idiom could depict someone picking an unripe fruit from a tree, symbolizing impatience and the consequences of hasty actions.

Actual idiom: ชิงหมาเกิด
Idiom meaning in English: Very bad (like a dog), a metaphor for a very bad and lowly person
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ชิงหมาเกิด" translates to "competing to be born as a dog." It is used to describe a situation where people are fighting or competing over something trivial or worthless. The imagery for this idiom could include people engaged in a heated argument or struggle, with a dog in the background, symbolizing the insignificance of what they are fighting over.

Actual idiom: ชี้นกเป็นนก ชี้ไม้เป็นไม้
Literal Translation: Point at a bird and it becomes a bird. Point at a tree and it becomes a tree.
English Pronounciation: Chi nok pen nok chi mai pen mai
Idiom meaning in English: No matter what the powerful say, the subordinates must follow along, either out of fear or flattery.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "ชี้นกเป็นนก ชี้ไม้เป็นไม้" translates to "Point at a bird, it's a bird; point at a tree, it's a tree." This idiom means that people accept things as they are presented or described by someone in authority or someone they trust. It emphasizes the power of perception and belief in authoritative figures. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a person pointing at a bird and a tree, with others around them nodding in agreement, symbolizing acceptance and trust in the person's words.

Actual idiom: ชุบมือเปิบ
Idiom meaning in English: Taking advantage of others without any effort or investment of your own.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ชุบมือเปิบ' (pronounced "chup mue pep") translates to "dipping one's hand to eat." It describes a situation where someone takes advantage of others' hard work without contributing any effort themselves. The imagery involves a person who simply dips their hand into a meal that others have prepared, enjoying the benefits without having participated in the preparation.

Actual idiom: เช้าชามเย็นชาม
Literal Translation: A bowl in the morning and a bowl in the evening
Idiom meaning in English: Lack of determination to work or not working to the fullest extent
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เช้าชามเย็นชาม" translates to "morning bowl, evening bowl" in English. It describes someone who is lazy or unproductive, doing the bare minimum to get by, such as only eating two meals a day without putting in much effort into anything else. An image representing this idiom might depict a person lounging around with a bowl of food in the morning and another in the evening, showing a lack of activity or motivation in between.

Actual idiom: เชื่อขนมกินได้
Idiom meaning in English: Sure, reliable, sure to succeed
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เชื่อขนมกินได้" translates to "You can trust it as you would trust eating sweets." It means that something is very reliable or trustworthy, just as you would trust that sweets are delicious. For an image, you might depict a person confidently eating a piece of candy or dessert, symbolizing trust and reliability.

Actual idiom: เชือดไก่ให้ลิงดู
Literal Translation: Slaughter a chicken for the monkey to see.
Idiom meaning in English: Punish one person or a group of people to serve as an example to others or groups of people so that they will be afraid and not dare to disobey orders or commit wrongdoings.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เชือดไก่ให้ลิงดู" translates to "Killing the chicken to show the monkey." It means making an example out of someone to serve as a warning to others. In a visual representation, you might depict a scene where a person is punishing or disciplining a chicken while a group of monkeys watches attentively, illustrating the idea of using one as a lesson for the others.

Actual idiom: ซื้อควายหน้านา ซื้อผ้าหน้าตรุษ
Literal Translation: Buy buffaloes in the rice fields, buy cloth in the Chinese New Year.
English Pronounciation: Sue khwai na na sue pha na trut
Idiom meaning in English: Buying things without considering the time will result in expensive things. doing things that are not suitable for the time will result in suffering.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ซื้อควายหน้านา ซื้อผ้าหน้าตรุษ" translates to "Buy a buffalo in the planting season, buy cloth before the New Year." It suggests that timing is crucial when making purchases or decisions. Just as buying a buffalo during the planting season ensures its usefulness and buying cloth before the New Year ensures readiness for celebrations, making decisions at the right time can lead to better outcomes.
