Literal Translation: No dog poop, no dog shit.
English Pronounciation: Mai mi mun foi ma mai khi
Idiom meaning in English: Without cause there is no effect.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ไม่มีมูลฝอยหมาไม่ขี้" translates to "If there is no trash, the dog won't poop." It means that rumors or accusations usually have some basis in truth. For an image representation, you might depict a scene with a dog near a trash pile, suggesting that the presence of trash (or evidence) leads to the dog's action (or the emergence of rumors).

Actual idiom: ไม่มีอะไรในกอไผ่
Literal Translation: There is nothing in the bamboo grove.
English Pronounciation: Mai mi arai nai ko phai
Idiom meaning in English: No unusual or suspicious things were found as rumored.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ไม่มีอะไรในกอไผ่" translates to "There is nothing in the bamboo clump." It means that there is no hidden agenda or secret behind a situation; everything is as it appears. For an image representation, you could depict a serene bamboo grove with clear visibility through the stalks, emphasizing transparency and the absence of hidden elements.

Actual idiom: ไม่ยอมลดราวาศอก
Idiom meaning in English: Never give in, never compromise, never compromise
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "ไม่ยอมลดราวาศอก" translates to "not willing to give an inch" in English. It describes a situation where someone is very stubborn or unyielding, refusing to compromise or back down from their position. 

For an image representation, you might depict two people standing firmly on either side of a line, each refusing to step back or give way, symbolizing their steadfastness and determination not to concede any ground.

Actual idiom: ไม่รู้จักเสือเอาเรือเข้ามาจอด ไม่รู้จักมอดเอาไม้เข้ามาขวาง
Literal Translation: Not knowing the tiger, bring a boat to park. Not knowing the termite, bring a stick to block.
English Pronounciation: Mai ruchak suea ao ruea khao ma chot mai ruchak mot ao mai khao ma khwang
Idiom meaning in English: Doing things that you don't know will cause harm to yourself.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): This Thai idiom translates to "Not knowing the tiger, you dock your boat; not knowing the termite, you block with wood." It means that acting without understanding the true nature of a situation or the potential dangers involved can lead to trouble. The imagery involves a boat docking near a tiger, unaware of the danger, and using wood to block termites, which will only attract them more.

Actual idiom: ไม่รู้จักหัวนอนปลายตีน
Literal Translation: Not knowing where one's head and foot are
English Pronounciation: Mai ruchak hua non plai tin
Idiom meaning in English: Don't know the background or history
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ไม่รู้จักหัวนอนปลายตีน' translates to "not knowing the head from the feet." It means being unfamiliar with someone or something, lacking knowledge about their background or origins. For an image, you might depict a person looking confused or puzzled, with a blurred or ambiguous figure in the background to symbolize the unknown or unfamiliar entity.

Actual idiom: ไม่รู้อีโหน่อีเหน่
English Pronounciation: Mai ru i no i ne
Idiom meaning in English: Not knowing what happened
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ไม่รู้อีโหน่อีเหน่' translates to "not knowing this or that" in English. It describes a situation where someone is completely unaware or uninformed about what is happening around them. For an image representation, you might depict a person standing in the middle of a chaotic scene, looking confused and oblivious to the events unfolding around them.

Actual idiom: ไม่ลดราวาศอก
Idiom meaning in English: Never give in, never compromise
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ไม่ลดราวาศอก' translates to "not giving an inch" in English. It describes a situation where someone is very stubborn or unyielding, refusing to compromise or back down. For an image representation, you might depict two people in a standoff, each firmly holding their ground, or a tug-of-war where neither side is willing to let go.

Actual idiom: ไม้เสียบผี
Idiom meaning in English: Very thin people
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ไม้เสียบผี" translates to "a stick used to impale a ghost." It is used to describe something or someone that is utterly useless or ineffective, often to the point of being a burden. The imagery suggests an object that serves no practical purpose, much like a stick that is futilely used against a ghost, which cannot be harmed by physical means.

Actual idiom: ไม้หลักปักขี้ควาย
Literal Translation: A stake planted in buffalo dung
Idiom meaning in English: Uncertain, uncertain
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ไม้หลักปักขี้ควาย" translates to "a wooden stake planted in buffalo dung." It describes someone who is unreliable or inconsistent, much like a stake that cannot stand firm when planted in something as unstable as dung. The imagery suggests a lack of stability and dependability.

Actual idiom: ไม้หลักปักเลน
Idiom meaning in English: Uncertain, uncertain
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ไม้หลักปักเลน" translates to "a post stuck in the mud." It describes a situation or a person that is unstable, unreliable, or easily swayed. The imagery suggests a wooden post that cannot stand firm because it is planted in soft, unstable mud, symbolizing a lack of steadfastness or consistency.

Actual idiom: ไม่เห็นน้ำตัดกระบอก ไม่เห็นกระรอกก่งหน้าไม้
Literal Translation: Don't see any water cutting the bamboo tube. I don't see any squirrels using crossbows.
English Pronounciation: Mai hen nam tat krabok mai hen krabok kong namai
Idiom meaning in English: Doing things in a hurry even though the time is not yet right
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "ไม่เห็นน้ำตัดกระบอก ไม่เห็นกระรอกก่งหน้าไม้" translates to "Don't cut the bamboo until you see the water; don't aim the crossbow until you see the squirrel." This idiom advises against taking action prematurely or making decisions without sufficient information or evidence. It emphasizes the importance of patience and careful observation before proceeding with any course of action. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a scene with a person holding a bamboo stick near a body of water, hesitating to cut it, and another person with a crossbow, waiting and watching for a squirrel to appear. The overall theme should convey the idea of waiting and observing before acting.

Actual idiom: ไม่เหลือบ่ากว่าแรง
Idiom meaning in English: It is not beyond one's ability to do so.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ไม่เหลือบ่ากว่าแรง" translates to "not beyond one's strength" in English. It means that a task or challenge is within one's capability to handle. For an image representation, you might depict a person confidently lifting a weight that is manageable for them, symbolizing that the effort required is within their power.

Actual idiom: ไม้อ่อนดัดง่าย ไม้แก่ดัดยาก
Literal Translation: Young wood is easy to bend, old wood is difficult to bend.
English Pronounciation: Mai on dat ngai mai kae dat yak
Idiom meaning in English: It is easier to discipline children to behave well than to discipline adults.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "ไม้อ่อนดัดง่าย ไม้แก่ดัดยาก" translates to "A young tree bends easily, an old tree bends with difficulty." This idiom means that it is easier to shape or influence someone when they are young and adaptable, but much harder to change someone who is older and set in their ways. 

For an image based on this idiom, you could depict a scene with two trees: one young and flexible, easily bending in the wind, and another older, thicker tree that stands rigid and unyielding. The background could include a natural setting, such as a forest or a garden, to emphasize the growth and age of the trees.

Actual idiom: ไม่เออออห่อหมก
Idiom meaning in English: Disagree, disapprove
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "ไม่เออออห่อหมก" translates to "not agreeing just to please others." It describes a person who does not simply go along with others' opinions or decisions for the sake of harmony or to avoid conflict. Instead, they stand by their own beliefs and express their true thoughts, even if it means disagreeing with the majority. 

For an image representation, you might depict a scene where one individual stands firm and speaks up in a group discussion, while others appear to be nodding in agreement. This visual can highlight the courage and integrity of the person who chooses to voice their own perspective rather than conforming.

Actual idiom: ไม่เอาถ่าน
Idiom meaning in English: Not good, not working seriously, not interested in work, frivolous
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ไม่เอาถ่าน" (mai ao than) translates to "not taking the charcoal" in English. It is used to describe someone who is lazy, unproductive, or unwilling to put in effort. The imagery suggests a person who won't even take the basic step of picking up charcoal to start a fire, symbolizing a lack of initiative or industriousness.

Actual idiom: ไม่เอาอ่าว
Idiom meaning in English: It's no good, it's no use, it's not right.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ไม่เอาอ่าว" translates to "not taking the bay" in English. It is used to describe someone who is incompetent or ineffective at their task. The imagery for this idiom could include a person standing by a bay, looking confused or unable to navigate a boat, symbolizing their inability to achieve their goal or perform their duties properly.

Actual idiom: ยกตนข่มท่าน
Idiom meaning in English: Praise yourself and put others down, talk down to others to show that you are superior.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ยกตนข่มท่าน" translates to "raising oneself while belittling others." It describes a situation where someone elevates their own status or achievements by putting others down. For an image representation, you might depict a person standing on a pedestal or platform, looking proud and confident, while others around them appear diminished or overshadowed. The visual contrast between the elevated individual and the subdued others would capture the essence of the idiom.

Idiom meaning in English: Give up
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ยกธงขาว" translates to "raise the white flag" in English. It signifies surrender or giving up in a situation. The imagery typically involves a person or group holding up a white flag, symbolizing their decision to stop fighting or resisting and to accept defeat or seek peace.

Idiom meaning in English: Guess, assume, make up stories
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ยกเมฆ' (Yok Mek) translates to "lifting the clouds" in English. It is used to describe someone who is making up stories or fabricating information, often to deceive or exaggerate. The imagery suggests creating something out of thin air, much like conjuring clouds from nothing.

Actual idiom: ยกหางตัวเอง
Idiom meaning in English: Praise yourself as good and skilled
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ยกหางตัวเอง" translates to "lifting one's own tail" in English. It describes someone who boasts or praises themselves excessively. The imagery suggests a person trying to elevate their own status or achievements, much like an animal lifting its tail to appear more prominent or important.

Actual idiom: ยศช้างขุนนางพระ
Literal Translation: The rank of the elephant of the noble monk
Idiom meaning in English: A title that is not important, not serious, and cannot bring benefits or harm to anyone.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ยศช้างขุนนางพระ" translates to "The rank of an elephant, the nobility of a monk." It suggests that just as an elephant is distinguished by its size and strength, and a monk by his spiritual nobility, people are often recognized and respected for their inherent qualities and roles. An image representing this idiom could feature a majestic elephant symbolizing strength and stature, alongside a serene monk embodying spiritual nobility and wisdom.

Actual idiom: ย้อมแมวขาย
Idiom meaning in English: Decorate people or things that are not good with the intention of deceiving others into believing that they are good.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ย้อมแมวขาย' translates to "dyeing a cat to sell it." It means to deceive someone by disguising something of lesser value as something more valuable. The imagery involves painting or dyeing a common cat to make it look like a more desirable or exotic animal, thereby tricking potential buyers. This idiom highlights the act of fraud or misrepresentation.

Actual idiom: ยักษ์ปักหลั่น
Idiom meaning in English: A person of large stature
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ยักษ์ปักหลั่น' (yak pak lan) translates to "a giant planting a post." It describes a situation where someone is undertaking a task that is far too easy for them, given their capabilities or strength. The imagery suggests a powerful giant performing a simple task, emphasizing the mismatch between the person's abilities and the simplicity of the task at hand.

Actual idiom: ย้ายสำมะโนครัวไปอยู่ในคุก
Literal Translation: Move the household register to prison
English Pronounciation: Yai sammano khrua pai yu nai khuk
Idiom meaning in English: In prison
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom 'ย้ายสำมะโนครัวไปอยู่ในคุก' translates to 'Moving the household registry to prison' in English. This idiom is used to describe a situation where someone is constantly in trouble or frequently ends up in jail, to the point where it seems like their permanent residence is in prison. It conveys the idea of habitual wrongdoing or a continuous cycle of criminal behavior. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a family or household items being moved into a prison cell, symbolizing the notion of making the prison their home.

Actual idiom: ยื่นแก้วให้วานร
Literal Translation: Hand the glass to the monkey
Idiom meaning in English: Give something valuable to someone who doesn't appreciate its value.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ยื่นแก้วให้วานร" translates to "handing a glass to a monkey." It means giving something valuable or delicate to someone who doesn't understand its value or how to use it properly. For an image, you could depict a monkey holding a fragile glass object, looking confused or indifferent, to illustrate the idea of entrusting something precious to someone who may not appreciate or handle it with care.

Actual idiom: ยืมจมูกคนอื่นหายใจ
Literal Translation: Borrowing someone else's nose to breathe
English Pronounciation: Yuem chamuk khon uen hai chai
Idiom meaning in English: Dependent on others is often inconvenient.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ยืมจมูกคนอื่นหายใจ' translates to 'borrowing someone else's nose to breathe.' It describes a situation where someone relies heavily on others to do things for them, rather than being self-reliant. For an image, you might depict a person with exaggeratedly large nostrils, symbolizing dependency, while another person is shown breathing through those nostrils, illustrating the act of relying on someone else for something as essential as breathing.

Actual idiom: ยุ่งเหมือนยุงตีกัน
Literal Translation: Busy like mosquitoes fighting each other
Idiom meaning in English: Confused, jumbled
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ยุ่งเหมือนยุงตีกัน" translates to "busy like mosquitoes fighting." It describes a situation that is extremely chaotic and disorganized, with many things happening at once, much like the frantic and erratic movement of mosquitoes when they are swarming and fighting. An image representing this idiom might depict a chaotic scene with numerous mosquitoes in a frenzied, disordered state, symbolizing confusion and busyness.

Idiom meaning in English: Blame, accuse, shift the burden to someone else (usually referring to a burden that one does not like)
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "โยนขี้" (pronounced "yon khee") translates to "throwing dung" in English. It metaphorically describes the act of shifting blame or responsibility onto someone else. In an image, this could be depicted by showing a person tossing a pile of dung towards another person, who looks surprised or upset, symbolizing the unfair transfer of blame.

Actual idiom: รวบหัวรวบหาง
Literal Translation: Gather all the heads and tails
Idiom meaning in English: Keep it short, get it done quickly, seize the opportunity when it's available.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "รวบหัวรวบหาง" (ruap hua ruap hang) translates to "grasping both the head and the tail." It means to take control of a situation from beginning to end or to manage all aspects of something comprehensively. An image representing this idiom could depict a person holding both ends of a snake or a rope, symbolizing complete control and management.

Actual idiom: ร่วมหอลงโรง
Idiom meaning in English: Live together as husband and wife, get married
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ร่วมหอลงโรง" (ruam ho long rong) translates to "sharing a hall and descending into a theater" in English. It metaphorically describes the act of getting married and starting a life together, emphasizing the commitment and shared experiences that come with marriage. An image based on this idiom could depict a couple standing together, perhaps in traditional wedding attire, with a backdrop that combines elements of a wedding hall and a theater stage, symbolizing the beginning of their shared journey and the various roles they will play in each other's lives.

Idiom meaning in English: A great number of different kinds
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ร้อยแปด' (pronounced "roi paet") translates to "one hundred and eight" in English. It is used to describe a situation with a vast variety of options, possibilities, or problems. The number 108 is symbolic, representing an extensive and diverse range of elements. An image to represent this idiom could include a collage of numerous different objects, activities, or scenarios, illustrating the concept of a multitude of choices or issues.

Actual idiom: ร้อยแปดพันเก้า
Literal Translation: One hundred and eight thousand and nine
Idiom meaning in English: A great number of different kinds
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom 'ร้อยแปดพันเก้า' (pronounced "roi paet pan gao") translates to "a hundred and eight, a thousand and nine" in English. It is used to describe a situation with a vast number of possibilities, variations, or complications. Essentially, it conveys the idea of something being extremely diverse or complex, with countless details or factors to consider.

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a scene filled with a multitude of different objects, paths, or elements, each representing the numerous possibilities or complexities. The image should evoke a sense of overwhelming variety and intricacy.

Actual idiom: ร้อยพ่อพันแม่
Literal Translation: Hundreds of fathers and thousands of mothers
Idiom meaning in English: People from many places come together, with different attitudes, beliefs, manners, behaviors, traditions, cultures, etc., due to different upbringings, education, and societies.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ร้อยพ่อพันแม่" translates to "a hundred fathers, a thousand mothers" in English. It describes a situation where a group of people comes from diverse backgrounds, each with different influences and upbringing. The imagery for this idiom could include a diverse group of individuals, each representing different cultures, traditions, or family backgrounds, symbolizing the variety and richness of their origins.

Actual idiom: รักดีหามจั่ว รักชั่วหามเสา
Literal Translation: Good love finds a pedestal, bad love finds a pillar.
English Pronounciation: Rak di ham chua rak chua ham sao
Idiom meaning in English: If you aspire to be good, you will be happy and prosperous. if you aspire to be bad, you will suffer hardship.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "รักดีหามจั่ว รักชั่วหามเสา" translates to "Love good, carry the ridge; love bad, carry the post." It means that those who love goodness and virtue will bear the responsibilities and rewards of a stable and honorable life (symbolized by carrying the ridge of a house, which is a high and important part), while those who love wickedness will bear the burdens and consequences of a troubled and dishonorable life (symbolized by carrying the post, which is a lower and more burdensome part). The imagery involves traditional house-building, where the ridge is a prestigious part of the structure, and the post is a heavy, foundational element.

Actual idiom: รักวัวให้ผูก รักลูกให้ตี
Literal Translation: If you love cows, tie them up; if you love children, beat them.
English Pronounciation: Rak wua hai phuk rak luk hai ti
Idiom meaning in English: When your child makes a mistake, you should discipline or punish them.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "รักวัวให้ผูก รักลูกให้ตี" translates to "If you love your cow, tie it up; if you love your child, discipline them." This idiom emphasizes the importance of care and discipline. Just as tying up a cow prevents it from wandering and getting into trouble, disciplining a child helps guide them and instill good behavior. The underlying message is that true love involves taking actions that ensure the well-being and proper development of those you care about.

Actual idiom: รับหน้าเสื่อ
Idiom meaning in English: Acting as a leader
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "รับหน้าเสื่อ" translates to "take the mat" in English. It means to take responsibility for a task or situation, often implying that the person is stepping up to handle something important or challenging. In a visual representation, you might depict someone stepping forward to take a mat or a symbolic item, indicating their readiness to assume responsibility.

Actual idiom: รำชั่วโทษพากย์
Idiom meaning in English: Doing something bad but blaming others
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "รำชั่วโทษพากย์" translates to "Blame the narrator for a bad dance." It means that when someone performs poorly, they often blame others for their own mistakes. In a visual representation, you might depict a dancer who is not performing well, pointing fingers at a narrator or commentator, suggesting that the fault lies with the narration rather than their own performance.

Actual idiom: รำไม่ดีโทษปี่โทษกลอง
Literal Translation: If you dance badly, blame the flute and the drums.
English Pronounciation: Ram mai di thot pi thot klong
Idiom meaning in English: Doing something bad or doing something wrong and not accepting responsibility, but instead blaming others.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "รำไม่ดีโทษปี่โทษกลอง" translates to "A bad dancer blames the flute and the drum." It means that someone who fails at a task often blames external factors rather than accepting responsibility for their own shortcomings. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a dancer who is visibly out of sync or clumsy, while in the background, musicians playing the flute and drum look confused or frustrated. The setting could be a traditional Thai performance stage to reflect the cultural context.

Actual idiom: รู้จักที่ต่ำที่สูง
Literal Translation: Know the high and low places
Idiom meaning in English: Know how to respect people and places according to one's status (often used in negative situations)
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "รู้จักที่ต่ำที่สูง" translates to "knowing the highs and lows" in English. It emphasizes the importance of understanding and respecting social hierarchies, roles, and the appropriate behavior in different situations. An image representing this idiom could depict a person bowing respectfully to someone of higher status, or a scene showing individuals acknowledging and respecting each other's positions in a community or organization.

Actual idiom: รู้หลบเป็นปีก รู้หลีกเป็นหาง
Literal Translation: Knowing how to dodge is like wings, knowing how to avoid is like a tail.
English Pronounciation: Ru lop pen pik ru lik pen hang
Idiom meaning in English: Know how to survive or adapt to situations.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "รู้หลบเป็นปีก รู้หลีกเป็นหาง" translates to "Knowing how to dodge is like having wings, knowing how to avoid is like having a tail." This idiom emphasizes the importance of being adaptable and resourceful in different situations. It suggests that just as wings and tails help birds navigate and survive, being able to skillfully dodge and avoid problems or dangers is crucial for success and survival in life.

Actual idiom: รู้หาญรู้ขลาด
Idiom meaning in English: Dare what you should dare, fear what you should fear.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "รู้หาญรู้ขลาด" translates to "knowing bravery, knowing cowardice." It emphasizes the importance of understanding both courage and fear, suggesting that wisdom lies in recognizing when to be brave and when to be cautious. An image representing this idiom could depict a person standing at a crossroads, with one path leading to a challenging mountain (symbolizing bravery) and the other to a safe, peaceful meadow (symbolizing caution).

Actual idiom: เรือขาดหางเสือ
Idiom meaning in English: Person who lacks awareness, a family without a responsible caretaker, a job without a boss.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เรือขาดหางเสือ" translates to "a boat without a rudder" in English. It describes a situation where there is a lack of direction, guidance, or leadership. The imagery involves a boat adrift on water, unable to steer or navigate properly because it is missing its rudder, symbolizing the essential component needed for control and direction.

Actual idiom: ไร้ญาติขาดมิตร
Idiom meaning in English: Having no relatives or friends who can provide support and rely on you.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ไร้ญาติขาดมิตร' translates to 'without relatives and friends' in English. It describes a situation where a person is isolated, lacking familial and social connections. An image representing this idiom might depict a solitary figure standing alone in a vast, empty landscape, emphasizing the sense of loneliness and isolation.

Actual idiom: ฤกษ์พานาที
Idiom meaning in English: Auspicious time period
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "ฤกษ์พานาที" (Rueak Pha Na Thi) translates to "an auspicious moment" in English. It emphasizes the importance of timing and choosing the right moment to undertake an action. The idiom suggests that success often depends on acting at the most favorable or opportune time. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a scene where someone is carefully observing a clock or a calendar, perhaps with elements like a sunrise or a blooming flower to symbolize the perfect timing. The overall theme should convey the idea of waiting for or recognizing the right moment to act.

Actual idiom: ฤๅษีแปลงสาร
Idiom meaning in English: Someone who changes the original text to have the opposite meaning.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ฤๅษีแปลงสาร" (Rue-Si Plaeng Sarn) translates to "The hermit distorts the message." It refers to a situation where someone intentionally misinterprets or alters information, often leading to misunderstandings or conflicts. The imagery for this idiom could include a wise-looking hermit or sage, perhaps with a long beard and traditional attire, holding a scroll or message that is visibly altered or twisted, symbolizing the act of distorting the original content.

Actual idiom: ฤๅษีเลี้ยงลิง
Idiom meaning in English: A naughty child caregiver or a group of people who are not disciplined will be distressed and annoyed.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ฤๅษีเลี้ยงลิง" translates to "A hermit raising a monkey." It describes a situation where a wise or disciplined person takes care of someone who is mischievous or unruly. The imagery involves a serene, wise hermit, often depicted in traditional Thai attire, trying to manage or care for a playful, chaotic monkey. This visual contrast highlights the challenge of maintaining order and wisdom in the face of disorderly behavior.

Idiom meaning in English: Help each other raise money for something.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ลงขัน" (long khan) translates to "contributing to a common cause" or "pooling resources together." It originates from the traditional practice where people would pour water into a shared container (ขัน) to collectively gather resources for a communal purpose, such as a village project or a community event. The image to represent this idiom could depict several hands pouring water or other resources into a single large bowl or container, symbolizing unity and collective effort.

Idiom meaning in English: Punish

Idiom meaning in English: Being far from the capital means that you don't know the news or stories.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หลังเขา" (pronounced "lang khao") translates to "behind the mountain" in English. It is used to describe someone who is considered unsophisticated, naive, or lacking in modern knowledge, often due to living in a remote or rural area. The imagery suggests a person who is isolated from contemporary developments and trends, much like someone living behind a mountain, away from the bustling life of the city.

Actual idiom: หลับให้สบาย
Idiom meaning in English: Used to express condolences for someone who has died.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หลับให้สบาย" translates to "Sleep well" in English. It conveys a wish for someone to have a restful and peaceful sleep, free from worries or disturbances. The imagery associated with this idiom might include a serene night scene, a comfortable bed, and a person sleeping peacefully, perhaps with a gentle smile, symbolizing tranquility and restfulness.

Idiom meaning in English: Being possessive of things that one has no right to, preventing others from using things that one has already used or cannot use.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หวงก้าง" (pronounced "huang kang") translates to "jealously guarding the bones" in English. It describes a situation where someone is possessive or protective over something of little value, often out of spite or stubbornness. The imagery involves a person clinging to the remnants of a fish, such as the bones, even though the valuable parts (the meat) are gone. This can be depicted as a person holding onto fish bones with a determined or stubborn expression, emphasizing the futility and pettiness of their actions.

Actual idiom: ห่วงคล้องคอ
Idiom meaning in English: Binding responsibilities
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ห่วงคล้องคอ" translates to "a ring around the neck" in English. It metaphorically describes a situation where someone is burdened or constrained by responsibilities, obligations, or problems that are difficult to escape from. The imagery suggests being trapped or held back by something that is constantly weighing one down.

Actual idiom: หวานเป็นลมขมเป็นยา
Literal Translation: Sweet is faint, bitter is medicine
English Pronounciation: Wan pen lom khom pen ya
Idiom meaning in English: Praise often makes us forget ourselves and lose our senses, but criticism is often useful and makes us think.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "หวานเป็นลมขมเป็นยา" translates to "Sweetness brings dizziness, bitterness brings medicine." This idiom suggests that things that are pleasant or easy (sweetness) can lead to negative consequences (dizziness), while things that are difficult or unpleasant (bitterness) can be beneficial or healing (medicine). It emphasizes the value of enduring hardship for long-term benefits. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a scene with contrasting elements: on one side, something sweet like a tempting dessert causing a person to feel faint or dizzy, and on the other side, something bitter like a medicinal herb or a bitter drink bringing relief or healing to another person.

Actual idiom: หว่านพืชหวังผล
Idiom meaning in English: Giving benefits to others in the hope of getting something in return
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "หว่านพืชหวังผล" translates to "Sow seeds with the hope of reaping a harvest" in English. This idiom conveys the idea that efforts and actions are undertaken with the expectation of achieving a desired outcome or reward. It emphasizes the principle of cause and effect, where diligent work and careful planning are expected to yield positive results.

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a farmer sowing seeds in a field, with a hopeful expression, and perhaps a vision or thought bubble showing a bountiful harvest of crops. This visual representation would capture the essence of putting in effort with the anticipation of future rewards.

Actual idiom: หอกข้างแคร่
Idiom meaning in English: Close person who may have evil thoughts at any time, usually used for adopted children who are attached to their father or mother, or enemies who are always by their side.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'หอกข้างแคร่' translates to "the spear beside the bed." It describes a situation where there is a hidden danger or threat very close to someone, often from someone within their own circle or household. The imagery suggests a sense of vulnerability and the need for caution, as the danger is lurking nearby and could strike at any moment.

Actual idiom: หอคอยงาช้าง
Idiom meaning in English: Those who are not interested in the problems or needs of the general public, are not aware of or do not consider the true state of society.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หอคอยงาช้าง" translates to "ivory tower" in English. It describes a place or situation where someone is isolated from the real world, often due to privilege or intellectual pursuits, and is therefore disconnected from practical concerns or everyday life. An image representing this idiom might depict a tall, elegant tower made of ivory, standing apart from a bustling, everyday scene below, symbolizing the separation between the isolated individual and the real world.

Idiom meaning in English: Take the liberty of forcing
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'หักคอ' (hak kho) translates to "breaking the neck" in English. It is often used metaphorically to describe a situation where someone is forced to comply or submit to something against their will, typically through coercion or pressure. The imagery for this idiom could involve a person being overpowered or subdued, symbolizing the act of being compelled to do something unwillingly.

Actual idiom: หักปากกาเซียน
Literal Translation: Breaking the pen of the expert
Idiom meaning in English: The results were not as predicted by experts.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หักปากกาเซียน" translates to "breaking the expert's pen." It signifies a situation where an expert or a highly knowledgeable person is proven wrong or fails despite their expertise. The imagery involves a pen, symbolizing the expert's tool or knowledge, being broken, indicating the fallibility of even the most skilled individuals.

Idiom meaning in English: They worked together first and then ended up causing harm later.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'หักหลัง' translates to 'stab in the back' in English. It describes a situation where someone betrays another person who trusted them. The imagery often associated with this idiom includes a person being unexpectedly attacked or betrayed from behind, symbolizing deceit and treachery.

Actual idiom: หันหน้าเข้าวัด
Idiom meaning in English: Head to the temple to observe the precepts, listen to sermons, etc.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หันหน้าเข้าวัด" translates to "turn one's face towards the temple." It signifies seeking spiritual guidance, moral support, or solace in times of trouble. The imagery often associated with this idiom includes a person looking towards a serene temple, symbolizing a quest for inner peace and wisdom.

Actual idiom: หันหน้าเข้าหากัน
Idiom meaning in English: Reconcile, unite
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หันหน้าเข้าหากัน" translates to "turning faces towards each other" in English. It symbolizes the act of coming together, engaging in open communication, and resolving conflicts through mutual understanding and cooperation. An image representing this idiom might depict two people facing each other, perhaps sitting at a table or standing in a friendly, conversational stance, emphasizing harmony and dialogue.

Actual idiom: หันหลังชนกัน
Idiom meaning in English: Join hands together
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หันหลังชนกัน" translates to "back to back" in English. It describes a situation where two people are in conflict or disagreement, standing with their backs to each other, symbolizing a lack of communication and cooperation. The imagery suggests a physical and emotional distance, highlighting the tension and separation between the individuals involved.

Actual idiom: หันหลังให้กัน
Literal Translation: Turn your backs on each other
Idiom meaning in English: Get angry with each other, stop being friends with each other
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หันหลังให้กัน" translates to "turning one's back on each other" in English. It describes a situation where two people are in disagreement, conflict, or have decided to end their relationship, symbolized by them facing away from each other. This imagery conveys a sense of separation, estrangement, or refusal to communicate.

Idiom meaning in English: Who is particularly talented or outstanding
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หัวกะทิ" (hua ka ti) translates to "coconut cream" in English. It refers to the best or most excellent part of something, similar to the "cream of the crop" in English. In a visual representation, you might depict a coconut being cracked open, with the rich, thick cream being separated from the rest of the coconut water and flesh, symbolizing the extraction of the finest quality.

Actual idiom: หัวแก้วหัวแหวน
Idiom meaning in English: Much loved, much favored
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หัวแก้วหัวแหวน" (hua kaew hua waen) translates to "the head of a gem, the head of a ring" in English. It is used to describe someone who is extremely precious and cherished, often referring to a beloved child or a highly valued person. The imagery suggests something of great value and beauty, akin to a precious gem or an exquisite ring, symbolizing the deep affection and importance placed on the individual.

Actual idiom: หัวชนกำแพง
Idiom meaning in English: Has a trait of never giving up
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หัวชนกำแพง" translates to "head against the wall" in English. It describes a situation where someone is persistently and stubbornly trying to achieve something despite facing insurmountable obstacles or resistance. The imagery suggests a person repeatedly banging their head against a wall, symbolizing futile efforts and the pain of relentless but unproductive persistence.

Idiom meaning in English: Has a trait of never giving up
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หัวชนฝา" translates to "head against the wall" in English. It describes a situation where someone is facing an insurmountable obstacle or is stubbornly persisting in a difficult or hopeless endeavor. The imagery suggests a person repeatedly hitting their head against a wall, symbolizing futile effort and frustration.

Actual idiom: หัวเดียวกระเทียมลีบ กลีบเดียวกระเทียมโทน
Literal Translation: One head of garlic, one clove of garlic
English Pronounciation: Hua diao krathiam lip klip diao krathiam thon
Idiom meaning in English: A single person but capable
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หัวเดียวกระเทียมลีบ กลีบเดียวกระเทียมโทน" translates to "a single head of shriveled garlic, a single clove of solo garlic." It metaphorically describes a situation where someone is alone and lacks support or resources, emphasizing the vulnerability and insufficiency of being solitary. The imagery of a single, shriveled garlic head and a lone garlic clove highlights the idea of being weak or ineffective when isolated.

Actual idiom: หัวเรี่ยวหัวแรง
Idiom meaning in English: The main force in carrying out various activities
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom 'หัวเรี่ยวหัวแรง' (hua riao hua raeng) translates to "the main force" or "the driving force" in English. It refers to a person who is the primary source of energy, effort, or leadership in a group or activity. This individual is often seen as the backbone or the most crucial contributor to the success of a project or endeavor.

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a strong, determined individual leading a group, perhaps carrying a heavy load or guiding others through a challenging task, symbolizing their role as the main driving force behind the collective effort.

Idiom meaning in English: The main force in carrying out various activities
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หัวแรง" (Hua Raeng) translates to "the main force" or "the driving force" in English. It refers to a person who is the key motivator or the most important contributor in a group or project. This individual is often seen as the leader or the one who puts in the most effort to ensure success. An image representing this idiom might depict a strong, determined individual leading a group, symbolizing their pivotal role in driving the collective effort forward.

Actual idiom: หัวล้านได้หวี
Idiom meaning in English: People who get things that are of no use to them
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หัวล้านได้หวี" translates to "A bald person receives a comb." It describes a situation where someone receives something that is of no use to them. The image could depict a bald person holding a comb with a puzzled or bemused expression, highlighting the irony and futility of the situation.

Idiom meaning in English: No, the negation of the meaning of the middle word
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หา…ไม่" translates to "searching for... but not finding" in English. It conveys the idea of looking for something persistently but being unable to find it. This can symbolize a futile search or an elusive goal. An image representing this idiom might depict a person searching intently, perhaps with a magnifying glass, in a vast, empty landscape or among scattered objects, emphasizing the fruitlessness of their quest.

Actual idiom: หาค่ามิได้
Idiom meaning in English: It is so valuable that it cannot be estimated.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หาค่ามิได้" translates to "priceless" or "invaluable" in English. It describes something so precious and valuable that it cannot be measured in terms of money or material worth. This could refer to intangible qualities such as love, wisdom, or time. An image representing this idiom might include a glowing treasure chest with no visible contents, symbolizing the immeasurable value within, or a serene scene of a family sharing a moment of joy, highlighting the priceless nature of love and togetherness.

Actual idiom: หายเข้ากลีบเมฆ
Idiom meaning in English: Disappeared and never seen again
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'หายเข้ากลีบเมฆ' translates to "disappearing into the clouds" in English. It describes a situation where someone or something vanishes suddenly and completely, as if they have been swallowed by the clouds, making them impossible to find or reach. This imagery evokes a sense of mystery and elusiveness.

Actual idiom: หาห่วงมาคล้องคอ
Literal Translation: Find a ring to hang around your neck.
Idiom meaning in English: Putting obligations on oneself
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'หาห่วงมาคล้องคอ' translates to "seeking a noose to put around one's own neck." It describes a situation where someone is knowingly putting themselves in a difficult or dangerous position, often due to their own actions or decisions. The imagery involves a person willingly placing a noose around their neck, symbolizing self-inflicted trouble or harm.

Actual idiom: หาเหาใส่หัว
Idiom meaning in English: Bringing trouble and annoyance to oneself
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หาเหาใส่หัว" translates to "looking for lice to put on your head." It means creating unnecessary problems or trouble for oneself. An image to represent this idiom could depict a person intentionally placing lice on their own head, symbolizing the act of inviting trouble or complications into their life.

Actual idiom: หุงข้าวประชดหมา ปิ้งปลาประชดแมว
Literal Translation: Cook rice to spite the dog, grill fish to spite the cat.
English Pronounciation: Hung khao prachot ma ping pla prachot maeo
Idiom meaning in English: Being sarcastic or sarcastic will only lead to negative consequences.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หุงข้าวประชดหมา ปิ้งปลาประชดแมว" translates to "Cooking rice to spite the dog, grilling fish to spite the cat." It describes a situation where someone does something out of spite or to show defiance, but the action ends up being futile or counterproductive. The imagery involves preparing food that would typically attract the animals (dogs and cats) rather than achieving the intended purpose of annoyance or defiance.

Idiom meaning in English: A person who is manipulated by others (usually used in a negative way)
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'หุ่นเชิด' translates to 'puppet' in English. It describes a situation where someone is being controlled or manipulated by another person, much like a puppet is controlled by a puppeteer. The imagery involves a figure with strings attached, being directed by an unseen hand, symbolizing the lack of autonomy and the influence of external forces.

Actual idiom: หูผีจมูกมด
Idiom meaning in English: Who is aware of or aware of the situation?
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "หูผีจมูกมด" translates to "ghost's ears, ant's nose" in English. It describes someone who is extremely perceptive and observant, able to notice even the smallest details or secrets, much like a ghost that can hear everything and an ant that can detect the tiniest scents. For an image, you might depict a person with exaggeratedly large ears and a keen, alert expression, perhaps with an ant nearby to symbolize their sharp senses.

Actual idiom: เห็นกงจักรเป็นดอกบัว
Literal Translation: See the wheel as a lotus flower
Idiom meaning in English: Seeing what is wrong as right, seeing wrong as right
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "เห็นกงจักรเป็นดอกบัว" translates to "seeing a cogwheel as a lotus." It describes a situation where someone perceives something harmful or dangerous as something beautiful or harmless. The cogwheel represents danger or harm, while the lotus symbolizes purity and beauty. This idiom warns against being deceived by appearances and failing to recognize the true nature of something. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a person looking at a cogwheel but seeing it as a lotus flower, highlighting the contrast between the dangerous reality and the deceptive appearance.

Actual idiom: เห็นเขาขึ้นคานหาม เอามือประสานก้น
Literal Translation: I saw him climb onto the stretcher and clasp his hands together at his buttocks.
English Pronounciation: Hen khao khuen khan ham ao mue prasan kon
Idiom meaning in English: Imitating important people or wealthy people even though one does not have the financial resources or ability to do so.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "เห็นเขาขึ้นคานหาม เอามือประสานก้น" translates to "Seeing someone being carried on a palanquin, they clasp their hands behind their back." This idiom describes a person who imitates others without understanding the context or the effort involved. It suggests a superficial attempt to emulate someone else's success or status without grasping the underlying work or significance. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a scene where one person is being carried on a traditional palanquin, symbolizing honor or achievement, while another person stands nearby, awkwardly clasping their hands behind their back, trying to mimic the posture without being part of the procession. The contrast between the two figures highlights the theme of imitation without comprehension.

Actual idiom: เห็นเขาขึ้นคานหาม เอามือประสานรัดก้น
Literal Translation: I saw him being carried on a stretcher, his hands clasped around his buttocks.
English Pronounciation: Hen khao khuen khan ham ao mue prasan rat kon
Idiom meaning in English: Imitating important people or wealthy people even though one does not have the financial resources or ability to do so.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เห็นเขาขึ้นคานหาม เอามือประสานรัดก้น" translates to "Seeing someone being carried on a palanquin, clasping hands behind one's back." It describes a situation where someone imitates or pretends to be in a position of importance or luxury without actually being in that position. The imagery involves a person observing another being carried in a palanquin (a symbol of high status) and then clasping their own hands behind their back as if they are also being carried, despite not being in the same situation. This idiom highlights the folly of pretending to be something one is not.

Actual idiom: เห็นช้างขี้ ขี้ตามช้าง
Literal Translation: If you see an elephant pooping, poop like the elephant.
English Pronounciation: Hen chang khi khi tam chang
Idiom meaning in English: Imitating important people or wealthy people even though one does not have the financial resources or ability to do so.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เห็นช้างขี้ ขี้ตามช้าง" translates to "Seeing an elephant defecate, you defecate after it." This idiom is used to describe someone who blindly follows others, especially in actions that may not be appropriate or suitable for them. It highlights the folly of imitating others without considering one's own circumstances or the consequences. An image representing this idiom might depict a smaller animal, like a mouse, attempting to mimic an elephant's actions, emphasizing the disparity and the absurdity of the imitation.

Actual idiom: เห็นช้างเท่าหมู
Literal Translation: Seeing an elephant as if it were a pig
Idiom meaning in English: Seeing an opponent who is bigger or more powerful, but not intimidating, when he is so angry that he forgets himself.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เห็นช้างเท่าหมู" translates to "seeing an elephant as the same size as a pig." It describes a situation where someone underestimates or fails to recognize the true magnitude or importance of something. The image could depict a person looking at an elephant and a pig, but perceiving them as being the same size, illustrating the concept of misjudgment or underestimation.

Actual idiom: เหยียบเรือสองแคม
Idiom meaning in English: Pretend to join both sides
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เหยียบเรือสองแคม" translates to "standing with a foot in two boats" in English. It describes a situation where someone is trying to balance or commit to two conflicting sides or interests at the same time, which is inherently unstable and likely to lead to failure. The imagery suggests a person with each foot in a different boat, struggling to maintain balance as the boats drift apart.

Actual idiom: แหงนคอตั้งบ่า
Literal Translation: Lift your neck and shoulders up
Idiom meaning in English: Lift your head up fully
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'แหงนคอตั้งบ่า' translates to "tilting one's head back until the neck is stiff." It describes a situation where someone is looking up with great admiration, awe, or aspiration, often to the point of being overwhelmed or overly ambitious. The imagery suggests a person gazing upward so intensely that their neck becomes strained, symbolizing the pursuit of lofty goals or admiration of something high above them.

Actual idiom: แหวกหญ้าให้งูตื่น
Literal Translation: Part the grass to startle the snake.
Idiom meaning in English: Doing something too blatantly that the other party will notice.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "แหวกหญ้าให้งูตื่น" translates to "stirring the grass to wake the snake." It means to unnecessarily provoke or disturb a situation, potentially causing trouble or danger. An image representing this idiom could depict a person parting tall grass with a stick, revealing an alert and potentially dangerous snake hidden within.

Actual idiom: อกสั่นขวัญแขวน
Idiom meaning in English: Extremely shocked, extremely frightened
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "อกสั่นขวัญแขวน" translates to "trembling with fear" in English. It describes a state of extreme fear or anxiety, where one's heart is pounding and their spirit feels as if it is hanging by a thread. To visualize this idiom, you might imagine a person with a frightened expression, clutching their chest, with a ghostly or shadowy figure looming over them, symbolizing the source of their fear.

Actual idiom: อกไหม้ไส้ขม
Idiom meaning in English: Suffering terribly
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "อกไหม้ไส้ขม" translates to "burning chest, bitter intestines" in English. It describes a state of intense emotional distress, often due to jealousy, anger, or deep sorrow. The imagery evokes a feeling of internal turmoil and suffering, as if one's insides are burning and bitter. For an image, you might depict a person clutching their chest with a pained expression, with flames or dark, swirling patterns around their torso to symbolize the burning and bitterness inside.

Actual idiom: อมพระมาพูด
Idiom meaning in English: Speaking by citing a monk or sacred object as evidence, often used in a negative context.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "อมพระมาพูด" translates to "holding a Buddha statue in your mouth while speaking." It means that even if someone swears on something sacred or holy, their words are still not trustworthy. The image could depict a person trying to speak with a small Buddha statue in their mouth, symbolizing the futility of their attempt to appear honest or credible.

Idiom meaning in English: Make comments that are irrelevant to the topic or event at that time or that are extremely bizarre.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ออกทะเล" (pronounced "awk ta-lay") translates to "go out to sea" in English. It is often used metaphorically to describe a situation where someone is straying off-topic or getting lost in their thoughts, much like a boat drifting aimlessly in the vast ocean. The imagery typically involves a small boat or person adrift on an expansive, open sea, symbolizing a lack of direction or focus.

Idiom meaning in English: Begin to show your bad deeds after pretending to be good.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ออกลาย" (pronounced "awk lai") translates to "showing one's true stripes" or "revealing one's true nature." It is often used to describe a situation where someone’s true character or intentions become apparent, especially if they have been hiding their real self. For an image representation, you might depict a person or animal shedding a disguise or mask, revealing their true form underneath.

Actual idiom: อ้อยเข้าปากช้าง
Idiom meaning in English: Things or benefits that fall into your hands and are not returned
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'อ้อยเข้าปากช้าง' translates to 'sugarcane in the elephant's mouth.' It describes a situation where something valuable or desirable has fallen into the hands of someone who will inevitably consume or use it all up, often implying that it is impossible to retrieve or recover it once given. The imagery involves an elephant, a large and powerful animal, enjoying a piece of sugarcane, which it will surely eat completely.

Actual idiom: อัฐยายซื้อขนมยาย
Literal Translation: Grandma bought some snacks for grandma.
Idiom meaning in English: Taking property from the guardian of the woman you are going to marry and giving it as a dowry to that woman's guardian with mutual consent. by implication, it means other actions of a similar nature, such as taking property from someone to buy or exchange for other things belonging to that person.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "อัฐยายซื้อขนมยาย" translates to "using grandmother's money to buy grandmother's sweets." It describes a situation where someone uses another person's resources to give something back to that same person, often implying a lack of genuine generosity or effort. For an image, you might depict a person taking money from an elderly woman and then buying sweets to give back to her, highlighting the circular and somewhat insincere nature of the act.

Actual idiom: อาบเหงื่อต่างน้ำ
Idiom meaning in English: Work hard with difficulty[1]
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "อาบเหงื่อต่างน้ำ" translates to "bathing in sweat instead of water." It describes someone who works extremely hard, to the point of sweating profusely, as if their sweat is replacing the need for a bath. This idiom emphasizes the value of hard work and dedication. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a person engaged in intense physical labor, with visible sweat pouring down their face and body, perhaps in a field or a workshop, highlighting their effort and perseverance.

Actual idiom: อายครูไม่รู้วิชา อายภรรยาไม่มีบุตร
Literal Translation: Am ashamed that my teacher does not know the subject. I am ashamed that my wife does not have children.
English Pronounciation: Ai khru mai ru wicha ai phanyaya mai mi but
Idiom meaning in English: Being ashamed of things that should not be shamed will lead to no benefit.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "อายครูไม่รู้วิชา อายภรรยาไม่มีบุตร" translates to "If you are too shy to ask the teacher, you won't gain knowledge; if you are too shy with your wife, you won't have children." This idiom emphasizes the importance of overcoming shyness or embarrassment in order to achieve important goals. It suggests that being too timid to seek help or communicate can lead to missed opportunities and unfulfilled potential.

Actual idiom: อาศัยลำแข้งตัวเอง
Idiom meaning in English: Help yourself
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'อาศัยลำแข้งตัวเอง' translates to "relying on one's own shins" in English. It means to depend on oneself and one's own efforts to achieve something, rather than relying on others. The imagery suggests using one's own legs to stand and move forward, symbolizing self-reliance and personal strength.

Actual idiom: เอาจมูกคนอื่นหายใจ
English Pronounciation: Ao chamuk khon uen hai chai
Idiom meaning in English: Dependent on others is often inconvenient.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เอาจมูกคนอื่นหายใจ" translates to "using someone else's nose to breathe." It describes a situation where someone relies too heavily on others to do things for them, rather than taking responsibility and doing it themselves. The imagery for this idiom could include a person attempting to breathe through another person's nose, symbolizing dependency and lack of self-reliance.

Actual idiom: เอาเนื้อหนูไปปะเนื้อช้าง
Literal Translation: Take the mouse meat and paste it on the elephant meat.
English Pronounciation: Ao nuea nu pai pa nuea chang
Idiom meaning in English: Taking wealth or things from those who have less and giving them to those who have more.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เอาเนื้อหนูไปปะเนื้อช้าง" translates to "Using mouse meat to patch up an elephant." It means attempting to solve a big problem with an inadequate or insignificant solution. The imagery involves a tiny mouse and a massive elephant, highlighting the disparity between the problem and the attempted fix.

Actual idiom: เอาปี๊บคลุมหัว
Literal Translation: Put a barrel over your head
Idiom meaning in English: I was so embarrassed that i didn't dare face anyone.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เอาปี๊บคลุมหัว" translates to "putting a bucket over one's head." It describes a situation where someone feels deeply embarrassed or ashamed, to the point where they want to hide their face from others. The imagery suggests a person covering their head with a bucket to avoid being seen due to their embarrassment.

Actual idiom: เอาปูนหมายหัว
Literal Translation: Take the lime and mark the head.
Idiom meaning in English: To hold a grudge, to blame, to believe that it will go as expected, to be careless and think that there is no way that it will be good.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เอาปูนหมายหัว" translates to "marking someone's head with lime." It means to falsely accuse someone or to blame someone without evidence. In a visual representation, you might depict a person being marked on the forehead with a white substance (lime) by another person, symbolizing the act of unjustly labeling or accusing them.

Actual idiom: เอามะพร้าวห้าวไปขายสวน
Literal Translation: Take the coconuts to sell in the orchard.
English Pronounciation: Ao maphrao hao pai khai suan
Idiom meaning in English: It's better to show off your knowledge to people who know more.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เอามะพร้าวห้าวไปขายสวน" translates to "Taking old coconuts to sell in the garden." It means trying to show off or sell something to someone who is already an expert or has plenty of it, implying that the effort is futile or redundant. For an image, you might depict a person carrying a basket of coconuts into a lush coconut grove, where the trees are already laden with coconuts.

Idiom meaning in English: Wanting to be praised, wanting to be favored
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เอาหน้า" (ao naa) translates to "taking the face" in English. It refers to someone who seeks to gain recognition, praise, or approval, often by taking credit for others' work or by showing off. The imagery for this idiom could depict a person stepping forward into the spotlight, perhaps with a smug expression, while others stand in the background, unnoticed or overshadowed.

Actual idiom: เอาหน้าไปไว้ที่ไหน
Literal Translation: Where did you put your face?
English Pronounciation: Ao na pai wai thi nai
Idiom meaning in English: How to face other people?
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เอาหน้าไปไว้ที่ไหน" translates to "Where will you put your face?" in English. It is used to express a sense of shame or embarrassment, often in situations where someone has done something disgraceful or humiliating. The imagery for this idiom could include a person looking down or covering their face in shame, symbolizing the feeling of wanting to hide one's face due to embarrassment.

Actual idiom: เอาหูไปนา เอาตาไปไร่
Literal Translation: Turn a deaf ear and a blind eye
English Pronounciation: Ao hu pai na ao ta pai rai
Idiom meaning in English: Pretend not to know, not to see, not to care
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เอาหูไปนา เอาตาไปไร่" translates to "Take your ears to the field, take your eyes to the farm." It means to ignore or pretend not to notice something. For an image representation, you might depict a person with exaggeratedly large ears and eyes, turning away or looking indifferent, while a busy field and farm scene unfolds in the background. This visual would capture the essence of deliberately ignoring or being oblivious to one's surroundings.

Actual idiom: ฮิตติดตลาด
Idiom meaning in English: Very popular, popular
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ฮิตติดตลาด' translates to "hit the market" in English. It describes something that has become extremely popular or trendy, often referring to products, ideas, or trends that have gained widespread acceptance and are in high demand. For an image representation, you might envision a bustling marketplace with a particular item or trend being highly sought after by many enthusiastic people, symbolizing its popularity and widespread appeal.

Idiom meaning in English: Very popular, popular
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom 'ฮิตติดลม' translates to "hit the wind" in English. It describes something that has become extremely popular or trendy, much like how a kite catches the wind and soars high. The imagery for this idiom could include elements that symbolize popularity and success, such as a kite flying high in the sky, a crowd of people excitedly engaging with a new trend, or a product that is in high demand.

Actual idiom: กระดูกขัดมัน
Idiom meaning in English: Very stingy and doesn't give anything to anyone easily.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "กระดูกขัดมัน" (pronounced "gra-duuk khat man") translates to "polished bone" in English. It describes a situation where someone is in a difficult or tight spot, often struggling to make ends meet or facing hardship. The imagery of a polished bone suggests something that has been worn down or stripped of its resources, much like a bone that has been cleaned of all its meat. This idiom is used to highlight the challenges and struggles someone might be enduring.

Actual idiom: กันดีกว่าแก้
Idiom meaning in English: Prevent incidents from occurring
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "กันดีกว่าแก้" translates to "Prevention is better than cure" in English. It emphasizes the importance of taking proactive measures to avoid problems rather than dealing with them after they arise. An image representing this idiom could depict a person putting up a fence to keep out potential dangers, symbolizing the act of preventing issues before they occur.

Actual idiom: กินน้ำไต้ศอก
Idiom meaning in English: I have to be inferior to him, not as good as him.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "กินน้ำไต้ศอก" (pronounced "gin nam tai sok") translates to "drinking water under the elbow." It describes a situation where someone is in a position of inferiority or subservience, often having to accept something less desirable or being treated with less respect. The imagery suggests a person who must drink water that has already flowed past someone else's elbow, symbolizing a lower status or a lack of dignity.

Actual idiom: กินอยู่กับปากอยากอยู่กับท้อง
Literal Translation: Eat with your mouth, want to be with your stomach.
English Pronounciation: Kin yu kap pak yak yu kap thong
Idiom meaning in English: You already know but pretend not to know.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "กินอยู่กับปากอยากอยู่กับท้อง" translates to "Eating is with the mouth, wanting is with the stomach." This idiom emphasizes the difference between satisfying immediate desires (eating with the mouth) and fulfilling deeper, more essential needs (wanting with the stomach). It suggests that while superficial desires can be easily satisfied, true needs require more consideration and effort. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a person with a content expression while eating, symbolizing immediate satisfaction, contrasted with a thoughtful or contemplative expression, representing deeper, unfulfilled needs. The background could include elements like a table with food and a serene setting to highlight the contrast between immediate gratification and deeper longing.

Actual idiom: กิ้งก่าได้ทอง
Idiom meaning in English: People who gain fame and fortune become arrogant and forget their original status.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "กิ้งก่าได้ทอง" translates to "A lizard gets gold." It describes a situation where someone who is not accustomed to wealth or luxury suddenly acquires it and behaves inappropriately or ostentatiously. The imagery for this idiom could include a lizard adorned with gold jewelry or sitting on a pile of gold, looking out of place or behaving extravagantly.

Actual idiom: แกงจืดจึงรู้คุณเกลือ
Literal Translation: Clear soup is known for its salty properties.
English Pronounciation: Kaeng chuet chueng ru khun kleua
Idiom meaning in English: We will know the value of things that we overlook and ignore only when they are gone.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "แกงจืดจึงรู้คุณเกลือ" translates to "One appreciates the value of salt when the soup is bland." This idiom means that people often do not recognize the importance of something or someone until it is missing or lacking. In a visual representation, you might depict a bowl of bland soup with a salt shaker nearby, emphasizing the idea that the soup's flavor is incomplete without the salt.

Actual idiom: ไก่งามเพราะขน คนงามเพราะแต่ง
Literal Translation: A chicken is beautiful because of its feathers, a person is beautiful because of their clothes.
English Pronounciation: Kai ngam phro khon ngam phro taeng
Idiom meaning in English: Beauty comes from decoration.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ไก่งามเพราะขน คนงามเพราะแต่ง" translates to "A chicken is beautiful because of its feathers; a person is beautiful because of their attire." This idiom suggests that outward appearances can be enhanced through adornment or grooming. It emphasizes the importance of presentation and how external enhancements can contribute to perceived beauty.

Actual idiom: ไก่เห็นตีนงูงูเห็นนมไก่
Literal Translation: The chicken sees the snake's feet, the snake sees the chicken's breasts.
English Pronounciation: Kai hen tin ngu ngu hen nom kai
Idiom meaning in English: Both parties know each other's secrets.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ไก่เห็นตีนงู งูเห็นนมไก่" translates to "The chicken sees the snake's feet, the snake sees the chicken's breasts." It means that two parties are aware of each other's secrets or faults. In a visual representation, you might depict a chicken and a snake observing each other closely, each with a knowing look, symbolizing mutual awareness of hidden truths.

Actual idiom: ไก่แก่หนังเหนียว
Idiom meaning in English: An old man with skill is hard to beat.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ไก่แก่หนังเหนียว" translates to "An old chicken has tough skin." It is used to describe someone who is experienced and resilient, often implying that they are not easily fooled or taken advantage of due to their wisdom and life experience. In a visual representation, you might depict an older, wise-looking chicken with a tough, textured skin, possibly standing confidently or in a thoughtful pose, symbolizing its hard-earned resilience and knowledge.

Actual idiom: ขนมจีนผสมน้ำยา
Idiom meaning in English: They are just right. you can't say which side is better.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ขนมจีนผสมน้ำยา" (khanom jeen phasom nam ya) translates to "fermented rice noodles mixed with curry." It is used to describe a situation where two things are combined or mixed together, often implying that they are a good match or complement each other well. The imagery involves a traditional Thai dish where the noodles and curry blend harmoniously, symbolizing a successful or harmonious combination.

Actual idiom: ขิงก็ราข่าก็แรง
Literal Translation: Ginger is old and galangal is strong.
English Pronounciation: Khing ko ra kha ko raeng
Idiom meaning in English: They are equally fierce, equally hot-tempered, and neither will give in.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ขิงก็ราข่าก็แรง" translates to "Both the ginger is moldy, and the galangal is spicy." It describes a situation where both parties involved are equally difficult, stubborn, or problematic. The imagery suggests that neither side is better or more agreeable than the other, highlighting mutual stubbornness or conflict.

Actual idiom: ขุนไม่เชื่อง
Idiom meaning in English: If you don't tame them, you will only become ungrateful.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ขุนไม่เชื่อง" translates to "An ungrateful person" in English. It describes someone who, despite being helped or nurtured, does not show gratitude or loyalty in return. The imagery often associated with this idiom might include a person turning their back on someone who has supported them, symbolizing ingratitude and betrayal.

Actual idiom: ข่มเขาโคขืน
Idiom meaning in English: Forcing others to do what you want, such as dressing them up to eat grass according to their mood, is like forcing a cow to eat grass.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ข่มเขาโคขืน" translates to "forcing a cow uphill." It describes a situation where someone is compelled to do something against their will or natural inclination, often leading to resistance and difficulty. The imagery involves a person trying to push or drive a cow up a steep hill, symbolizing an arduous and unnatural effort.

Actual idiom: ข่มเขาโคขืนให้กลืนหญ้า
Literal Translation: Force the cows to swallow the grass.
English Pronounciation: Khom khao kho khuen hai kluen ya
Idiom meaning in English: Forcing others to do what you want
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ข่มเขาโคขืนให้กลืนหญ้า" translates to "forcing a cow to swallow grass." It describes a situation where someone is compelled to do something against their will or natural inclination. The imagery involves a person trying to make a cow eat grass forcefully, highlighting the futility and resistance involved in such an action. This idiom is often used to illustrate the pointlessness or difficulty of trying to make someone do something they are not inclined to do.

Actual idiom: ข้างนอกขรุขระข้างในต๊ะติ๊งโหน่ง
English Pronounciation: Khang nok khrurakha khang nai ta ting nong
Idiom meaning in English: Things that may not look beautiful or good on the outside, but actually have beauty or goodness hidden inside.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ข้างนอกขรุขระข้างในต๊ะติ๊งโหน่ง" translates to "Rough on the outside, but delightful on the inside." It describes something or someone that may appear unrefined, harsh, or unattractive externally, but possesses inner qualities that are pleasant, valuable, or enjoyable. This idiom emphasizes the importance of not judging based solely on outward appearances.

Actual idiom: ข้างนอกสุกใสข้างในเป็นโพรง
English Pronounciation: Khang nok suk sai khang nai pen phong
Idiom meaning in English: Things that look beautiful on the outside, but are actually bad on the inside.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "ข้างนอกสุกใสข้างในเป็นโพรง" translates to "Outside is shiny, inside is hollow." This idiom describes something or someone that appears attractive or impressive on the outside but lacks substance or value on the inside. It highlights the importance of looking beyond external appearances to understand the true nature or quality of something.

Actual idiom: เขียนด้วยมือลบด้วยเท้า
Literal Translation: Write with hand, erase with foot
English Pronounciation: Khian duai mue lop duai thao
Idiom meaning in English: Praise and then destroy later
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "เขียนด้วยมือลบด้วยเท้า" translates to "written with the hand, erased with the foot." It describes a situation where someone makes a commitment or promise (symbolized by writing with the hand) but then carelessly or disrespectfully breaks it (symbolized by erasing with the foot). This idiom highlights the inconsistency and lack of integrity in a person's actions. 

For an image representation, you might visualize a hand writing something important on a piece of paper, while a foot is poised to smudge or erase the writing, symbolizing the act of breaking a promise or commitment.

Actual idiom: เข้าทางตรอกออกทางประตู
Literal Translation: Enter through the alley and exit through the door.
English Pronounciation: Khao thang trok ok thang pratu
Idiom meaning in English: Following the customs of asking for a hand in marriage, the young man and woman who are in love with each other respect each other, enter through the alley and leave through the door, so to speak.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "เข้าทางตรอกออกทางประตู" translates to "Enter through the alley, exit through the door." It means to start something in a humble or modest way and finish it in a grand or proper manner. For an image representation, you might depict a person entering a small, narrow alleyway and then emerging through a large, ornate door, symbolizing the transition from modest beginnings to a more significant or formal conclusion.

Actual idiom: คนตายขายคนเป็น
Literal Translation: Dead people sell to living people
Idiom meaning in English: Holding a grand funeral for the deceased even though the deceased are poor and have no money or have borrowed money until they are in debt.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Thai idiom "คนตายขายคนเป็น" translates to "The dead sell the living." It means that the actions or legacy of those who have passed away can significantly impact the lives of those who are still living. This could be interpreted as the deceased leaving behind a reputation, debts, or responsibilities that the living must deal with. 

For an image representation, you might consider depicting a scene where a ghostly figure or a tombstone is connected by a chain to a living person, symbolizing the ongoing influence or burden left by the deceased.

Actual idiom: คนรักเท่าผืนหนังคนชังเท่าผืนเสื่อ
Literal Translation: People who love you are as big as a piece of skin, people who hate you are as big as a mat.
English Pronounciation: Khon rak thao phuen nang khon chang thao phuen suea
Idiom meaning in English: There are few lovers, many haters.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
Certainly! The Thai idiom "คนรักเท่าผืนหนังคนชังเท่าผืนเสื่อ" translates to "Those who love you are as few as a piece of leather, those who hate you are as many as a mat." This idiom suggests that genuine love and support are rare and precious, while animosity and criticism are abundant and widespread. 

For an image based on this idiom, you might depict a small, valuable piece of leather symbolizing the few who truly love and support you, contrasted with a large, common mat representing the many who harbor negative feelings or criticism.

Actual idiom: คนล้มอย่าข้าม
Literal Translation: Don't step on someone who has fallen.
Idiom meaning in English: People who used to have power and influence but lost power, don't make things worse for them because they may come back to power again.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): The Thai idiom "คนล้มอย่าข้าม" translates to "Do not step over a fallen person."
