Idiom meaning in English: Success breeds success.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “সাফল্য সাফল্য ডাকে” translates to “Success calls to success” in English. It means that accomplishment breeds further opportunities.
The image can be depicted as a lamp lighting another candle in succession, each flame brighter than the last—showing how one victory kindles the next.

Literal Translation: Master of many, expert of none.
Idiom meaning in English: Jack of all trades, master of none.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “বহু বিদ্যায় কাহারো ওস্তাদ নয়” translates to “Of much learning, no one is master” in English. It humbly acknowledges that knowledge’s depth eludes even the most learned.
The image can be depicted as an open book whose pages stretch infinitely Vanishing into mist—reminding us that scholarship is a lifelong pursuit.

Literal Translation: Patience is bitter, fruit is sweet.
Idiom meaning in English: Patience is hard, but rewarding.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “ধৈর্য তেতো, ফল মিষ্টি” translates to “Patience is bitter, but its fruit is sweet” in English. It counsels enduring hardship now for greater reward later.
The image can be depicted as a traveler sipping bitter tonic by a thorny path, then arriving at an orchard of ripe, luscious fruit—emphasizing the payoff of perseverance.

Actual idiom: সময় ও নদীর স্রোত কারো জন্য অপেক্ষা করে না।
Literal Translation: Time and tide wait for none.
English Pronounciation: Shomoy o nodir srot karo jonno opekkha kore na
Idiom meaning in English: Time waits for no one.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “সময় ও নদীর স্রোত কারো জন্য অপেক্ষা করে না” translates to “Time and the river’s flow wait for no one” in English. It reminds us that both life and nature move relentlessly forward.
The image can be depicted as a clock with hands melding into a rushing river current, carrying leaves downstream—highlighting the unstoppable march of hours.

Actual idiom: সময়ের এক ফোঁড়, অময়ের দশ ফোঁড়।
Literal Translation: One stitch in time saves nine.
English Pronounciation: Shomoyer ek phor, omoyer dosh phor
Idiom meaning in English: Timely action prevents bigger problems.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “সময়ের এক ফোঁড়, অময়ের দশ ফোঁড়” translates to “A stitch in time saves nine” in English. It stresses that timely small efforts prevent much greater toil later.
The image can be depicted as a single neat stitch halting a growing tear in cloth—while unchecked, the tear would widen drastically—underscoring the economy of prompt action.

Literal Translation: Drop by drop, water makes the sea.
Idiom meaning in English: Small efforts add up to big results.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “বিন্দু বিন্দু জল সাগর হয়” translates to “Drop by drop, water makes the ocean” in English. It teaches that small contributions accumulate into greatness.
The image can be depicted as a single droplet falling into a growing pool that expands into a vast sea—illustrating how incremental effort achieves magnitude.

Idiom meaning in English: Time heals and destroys all.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “সময়ই ক্ষয় শুকায়” translates to “Time alone dries decay” in English. It means that only time heals or resolves the deepest wounds.
The image can be depicted as a broken pot gradually sealed by layers of sediment over seasons—symbolizing restoration through the passage of years.

Literal Translation: Wasting time is the greatest waste.
Idiom meaning in English: Time is the most valuable resource.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “সময়ের অপচয় বড় অপচয়” translates to “Wasting time is the greatest waste” in English. It reminds us that lost moments cannot be reclaimed.
The image can be depicted as an hourglass with sand slipping through a hole in its side—losing grains beyond the glass—emphasizing time’s irretrievability.

Literal Translation: When time is gone, nothing can be done.
Idiom meaning in English: Lost time cannot be regained.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “সময় গেলে সাধন হয় না” translates to “Once the time passes, practice cannot catch up” in English. It warns that opportunities missed cannot be reclaimed by effort alone.
The image can be depicted as a wilted flower beside a closed door labeled “Opportunity,” while a hopeful hand reaches in vain—highlighting regret over lost chances.

Idiom meaning in English: Patience is rewarded.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “ধৈর্য্য ফল দেয়” translates to “Patience bears fruit” in English. This proverb teaches that enduring hardship and waiting calmly often lead to rewarding outcomes.
The image can be depicted as a gardener tending a sapling through sun and rain, patiently watering it, until it blossoms into a tree heavy with ripe fruit—illustrating that steady care and perseverance yield bounty.

Idiom meaning in English: Honesty is the best path.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “সততা শ্রেষ্ঠ পন্থা” translates to “Honesty is the best policy” in English. This saying asserts that truthfulness and integrity are the surest ways to earn trust and lasting success.
The image can be depicted as a traveler at a crossroads choosing the clear, straight path bathed in sunlight over shadowy side trails—symbolizing that honesty lights the way more surely than deceit.

Idiom meaning in English: Let others live as you do.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “বাঁচো এবং বাঁচতে দাও” translates to “Live and let live” in English. It advocates tolerance and mutual respect.
The image can be depicted as two birds sharing a branch, each singing its own song without disturbing the other—symbolizing peaceful coexistence.

Actual idiom: আকাশ যদি পড়ে, আমরা চড়ুই ধরব।
Literal Translation: If the sky falls, we’ll catch sparrows.
English Pronounciation: Akash jodi pore, amra chorui dhorbo
Idiom meaning in English: Don’t worry about the impossible.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “আকাশ যদি পড়ে, আমরা চড়ুই ধরব” translates to “If the sky falls, we’ll catch sparrows” in English. It humorously suggests readiness to make the best of an impossible disaster.
The image can be depicted as villagers poised with nets under a crumbling blue sky raining tiny birds—highlighting resilient improvisation amid calamity.

Actual idiom: এক বার না পারিলে দেখো শতবার
Literal Translation: If you don't succeed once, try a hundred times
English Pronounciation: Ek bar na parile dekho shatobar
Idiom meaning in English: The importance of persistence and determination, suggesting that if you fail once, you should keep trying until you succeed
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “এক বার না পারিলে দেখো শতবার” translates to “If at first you don’t succeed, try a hundred more times” in English. It inspires unwavering persistence.
The image can be depicted as an archer missing the target repeatedly but drawing and releasing arrow after arrow—each shot closer—emphasizing tenacity.

Idiom meaning in English: Caution prevents harm.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “সাবধানের মার নেই” translates to “There is no greater shield than caution” in English. It underscores that foresight and care prevent harm better than any armor.
The image can be depicted as a pedestrian carefully stepping over cracks on a pavement while others dash heedlessly—showing that prudence averts danger.

Idiom meaning in English: The brave are rewarded.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “সাহসীরই লক্ষ্মী হয়” translates to “Fortune favors the brave” in English. It proclaims that bold actions often reap the greatest rewards.
The image can be depicted as an adventurer bravely leaping across a chasm to reach a treasure chest glowing on the other side—illustrating the payoff of courage.

Literal Translation: Joy and sorrow come in turns.
Idiom meaning in English: Life has ups and downs.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
This Bengali idiom, "সুখ-দুঃখ পালাক্রমে আসে" (Shukh-Dukkho Palakrome Ashe), means that "Happiness and sorrow come in turns." This idiom means that joy and sorrow are inherent parts of life that visit everyone in alternating cycles. It underscores the impermanent nature of both good and bad times, offering solace during hardship and a reminder of life's fluctuating nature during periods of ease.

For a powerful image, envision a pendulum swinging gracefully between two illuminated spheres labeled 'Happiness' and 'Sorrow', with a single figure watching its steady, inevitable movement, symbolizing the cyclical nature of life's fortunes.

Idiom meaning in English: Everyone gets their chance.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
This Bengali idiom, "প্রতিটি কুকুরেরও একদিন আসে" (Protiti Kukurero Ekdin Ashe), means that "Every dog has its day." This idiom means that everyone, regardless of their current humble or challenging circumstances, will eventually experience a moment of triumph, success, or favorable fortune. It offers a hopeful perspective that even the most overlooked individual will have their turn to shine or find justice.

For a powerful image, envision a small, overlooked dog patiently waiting in a gloomy alley, while a single, brilliant spotlight suddenly illuminates it, transforming the alley into a grand stage, symbolizing an unexpected moment of recognition or triumph.

Idiom meaning in English: Good times are fleeting.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
This Bengali idiom, "সুখের সময় দ্রুত চলে যায়" (Sukher Shomoy Druto Chole Jay), means that "Happy times pass quickly." This idiom means that periods of joy, contentment, and prosperity often feel fleeting and seem to pass by more rapidly than times of hardship or difficulty. It's a common reflection on the transient nature of pleasant experiences.

For a powerful image, envision a vibrant, joyful scene—perhaps a sunlit picnic—with a clock's hands spinning at an impossibly fast rate, blurring the joyful faces and turning day into dusk in an instant, symbolizing the rapid passage of happy moments.

Actual idiom: সুযোগ হারালে আর পাওয়া যায় না।
English Pronounciation: Sujog harale ar pawa jay na
Idiom meaning in English: Don’t miss your chance.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
This Bengali idiom, "সুযোগ হারালে আর পাওয়া যায় না" (Shujog Harale Ar Pawa Jay Na), means that "If an opportunity is lost, it cannot be found again." This idiom means that opportunities are often transient and unique; once they pass by or are missed due to inaction or oversight, they may not recur. It emphasizes the importance of seizing favorable moments and acting decisively when chances arise.

For a powerful image, envision a single, luminous golden key briefly appearing in an open lock, but as a hesitant hand reaches for it, the key instantly fades and the lock snaps shut, leaving no trace, symbolizing a lost, irretrievable opportunity.

Actual idiom: ক্ষমতা পেলে মানুষ খারাপ ব্যবহার করে।
Literal Translation: People misuse power when they have it.
English Pronounciation: Khomota pele manush kharap byabohar kore
Idiom meaning in English: Power corrupts.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
This Bengali idiom, "ক্ষমতা পেলে মানুষ খারাপ ব্যবহার করে" (Kh क्षमता Pele Manush Kharap Byobohar Kore), means that "When people get power, they misuse it." This idiom means that individuals, upon gaining authority or influence, often succumb to its corrupting effects, leading them to become arrogant, oppressive, or unjust in their dealings with others. It highlights the tendency for power to reveal or exacerbate negative character traits.

For a powerful image, envision a person being handed a glowing scepter of power, and as they grasp it, their benevolent face contorts into a shadowed, cruel expression, with their hand immediately pointing to oppress smaller figures below, symbolizing the corrupting influence of authority.

Literal Translation: If you pull the ear, the head comes down.
Idiom meaning in English: A small correction or punishment can bring someone to their senses or make them more obedient.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
This Bengali idiom, "কান টানলে মাথা আসে" (Kan Tanle Matha Ashe), means that "If you pull the ear, the head comes along." This idiom implies that addressing a minor or easily accessible part of a problem will naturally lead to the resolution or understanding of the larger, connected issue. It suggests an inherent connection between things, where tackling one aspect inevitably brings the other into focus, or that a small correction can lead to a complete change in behavior or situation.

For a powerful image, envision a single, small string gently tugged, which then effortlessly pulls a massive, complex mechanism into alignment, symbolizing how a minor action or solution can reveal or control a larger, connected system.

Actual idiom: সুখ-দুঃখের দিন কারও চিরস্থায়ী হয় না।
Literal Translation: Days of joy and sorrow are not permanent for anyone.
English Pronounciation: Sukh Dukher din karo chirosthai hoyna.
Idiom meaning in English: Every dog has his day.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
This Bengali idiom, "সুখ-দুঃখের দিন কারও চিরস্থায়ী হয় না" (Shukh-Dukkher Din Karor Chirosthayi Hoy Na), means that "Days of happiness and sorrow are not permanent for anyone." This idiom means that no one's circumstances, whether fortunate or unfortunate, are everlasting. It embodies the universal truth that life is a continuous cycle of ups and downs, reminding individuals that neither joy nor sorrow will persist indefinitely, thereby offering both hope during adversity and a sense of humility during prosperity.

For a powerful image, envision a rotating wheel of fortune, with segments depicting both bright, sunny landscapes and dark, stormy scenes, where a figure stands fixed, experiencing each segment as the wheel steadily turns, symbolizing that no one's situation remains permanent.

Actual idiom: কার নয়নে কারে লাগে যে ভালো
Literal Translation: Whatever looks good to one's eyes, they find it nice.
English Pronounciation: Kar noyone kare lagey je bhalo
Idiom meaning in English: People appreciate things based on their personal preferences and biases.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation): This bengali idiom কার নয়নে কারে লাগে যে ভালো suggests that people tend to appreciate things based on their personal preferences or biases. It reflects subjective judgments influenced by individual tastes. Imagine an image of a person admiring a beautiful landscape or artwork, with a smile on their face. The setting should be serene and pleasing, capturing the essence of personal appreciation and subjective beauty.

Literal Translation: The straight run of a blind horse
Idiom meaning in English: A situation where someone, despite lacking the necessary skills or abilities, succeeds by sheer luck or by chance
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “কানা ঘোড়ার সিধা দৌড়” translates to “A one-eyed horse runs straight” in English. This proverb suggests that someone with limited vision or abilities will stick to a safe, straightforward path rather than risk detours.
The image can be depicted as a horse missing one eye trotting confidently along a perfectly straight road—emphasizing that its narrow sight keeps it from straying.

Literal Translation: Someone's game and someone else's pain
Idiom meaning in English: Where one person's success causes harm or suffering to another, highlighting an imbalance or unfairness.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “কারোর খেলা আর কারোর জালা” translates to “One’s sport is another’s snare” in English. It warns that what seems harmless fun to one person may trap or harm someone else.
The image can be depicted as two neighbors: one gleefully playing with a hoop, the other entangled in a hidden net—highlighting how one’s amusement can ensnare another.

Literal Translation: Finish work while the opportunity is there.
Idiom meaning in English: Make the most of your opportunities.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “সুযোগ থাকতেই কাজ গুছিয়ে নাও” translates to “Gather your tools while opportunity lasts” in English (akin to “Make hay while the sun shines”). It advises preparing or acting promptly before the chance slips away.
The image can be depicted as a woodcutter swiftly sharpening his axe under a bright sun—symbolizing readiness in moments of favor.

Actual idiom: বিপদে বন্ধু বরং অন্যরকমই হয়, বিপদে হায়! হায়! কেউ কারও নয়।
Literal Translation: In trouble, friends act differently; in trouble, no one is there.
English Pronounciation: Bipode bondhu borong onnyorokomi hoy, bipode hay hay keu karo noy
Idiom meaning in English: True friends are rare in trouble.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “বিপদে বন্ধু বরং অন্যরকমই হয়, বিপদে হায়! হায়! কেউ কারও নয়” translates to “In danger, friends act differently; when trouble comes, alas! no one stands by another” in English. It laments that true solidarity often vanishes when hardship strikes.
The image can be depicted as a lone pilgrim caught in a storm calling for help, while shadowy figures disperse into the night—illustrating desertion in crisis.

Actual idiom: সে রামও নেই সে অযোধ্যাও নেই
Literal Translation: Neither Ram nor Ayodhya is left.
English Pronounciation: Shey Ram-o nei, shei Ayodhya-o nei
Idiom meaning in English: Everything is lost.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “সে রামও নেই সে অযোধ্যাও নেই” translates to “No Ram, no Ayodhya” in English. It means that without the essential element, the entire result collapses—if the hero vanishes, so does his kingdom.
The image can be depicted as empty palace gates flung wide, with a lone throne standing in desolate ruins—emphasizing that place and purpose vanish without their core.

Literal Translation: Killing the goose that lays golden eggs.
Idiom meaning in English: Destroying a good source for short-term gain.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “সোনার ডিম পাড়া হাঁস মারা” translates exactly to “Killing the goose that lays golden eggs” in English. It warns against destroying a steady source of benefit for short-term gain.
The image can be depicted as a farmer bludgeoning a golden-egg-laying goose, eggs shattering on the ground—underscoring the folly of destroying one’s treasure.

Idiom meaning in English: A wife’s advice is valuable.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “স্ত্রী বুদ্ধি প্রেয়ংকারী” translates to “A wife’s wit is captivating” in English. It suggests that a woman’s intelligence is often more alluring than her beauty.
The image can be depicted as a smiling wife unraveling a knot with clever hands, her husband watching in admiration—highlighting intellect as charm.

Actual idiom: স্থির মস্তিষ্ক না হলে উন্নতি করা যায় না।
Literal Translation: Without a calm mind, progress is impossible.
English Pronounciation: Sthir mastishko na hole unnati kora jay na
Idiom meaning in English: Calmness is needed for success.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “স্থির মস্তিষ্ক না হলে উন্নতি করা যায় না” translates to “Without a steady mind, progress is impossible” in English. It underscores that clear, focused thought is the foundation of advancement.
The image can be depicted as a scholar meditating calmly beneath a stormy sky, a path unfolding ahead with each breath—symbolizing inner calm guiding outward growth.

Idiom meaning in English: Be direct and honest.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “স্পষ্ট কথা বলো” translates to “Speak plainly” in English. It advises eliminating ambiguity and stating one’s meaning directly.
The image can be depicted as a person removing a veil from their mouth to let bright words stream forth—illustrating the clarity of unvarnished speech.

Actual idiom: স্বর্গের দাসত্ব অপেক্ষা নরকের রাজত্ব শ্রেয়।
Literal Translation: Better to rule in hell than serve in heaven.
English Pronounciation: Sworger dasotto opeksha noroker rajotto shreyo
Idiom meaning in English: Independence is better than servitude.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “স্বর্গের দাসত্ব অপেক্ষা নরকের রাজত্ব শ্রেয়” translates to “Better to rule in hell than serve in heaven” in English. It proclaims that autonomy, even in dire circumstances, is preferable to subservience in comfort.
The image can be depicted as a lone sovereign wielding a crown amid fiery ruins, while guided souls bow in gilded halls—emphasizing the value of independence over ease

Actual idiom: স্বভাব যায় না মরে, আর ইলিশ যায় না ধোয়ে।
Literal Translation: Nature doesn’t change by dying, nor does hilsa lose its smell by washing.
English Pronounciation: Swabhav jay na more, ar ilish jay na dhoye
Idiom meaning in English: True nature never changes.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “স্বভাব যায় না মরে, আর ইলিশ যায় না ধোয়ে” translates to “Nature doesn’t change with death, nor does hilsa lose its oil by washing” in English. It teaches that inherent traits persist despite external efforts to mask or cleanse them.
The image can be depicted as a silver-skinned hilsa fish shedding water under a faucet while oily sheen remains—highlighting the stubbornness of essence.

Idiom meaning in English: Cheap things often cause trouble.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “সস্তার জিনিসে অবস্থা খারাপ” translates to “Cheap goods breed disrepair” in English. It warns that cutting corners on quality leads to failure and frustration.
The image can be depicted as a rickety chair bought at a bargain collapsing beneath its sitter—underscoring that low price often signals low durability.

Idiom meaning in English: Relying on oneself is best.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “স্বনির্ভরতা সর্বোৎকৃষ্ট নির্ভরতা” translates to “Self-reliance is the highest reliance” in English. It extols independence as the most trustworthy support.
The image can be depicted as a lone mountaineer planting a flag atop a peak without assistance—symbolizing triumph born of one’s own effort.

Idiom meaning in English: God helps those who help themselves.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “স্বনির্ভরদের ঈশ্বরও সাহায্য করেন” translates to “God helps those who help themselves” in English. It affirms that divine aid favors those who take initiative.
The image can be depicted as a laborer pushing a cart uphill under a divine ray of light—portraying heavenly support for resolute endeavor.

Literal Translation: A panting dog is of no use.
Idiom meaning in English: The exhausted are of no use.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “হাঁপানো কুকুরে কাজ হয় না” translates to “A panting dog gets nothing done” in English. It means those who exhaust themselves with needless haste accomplish little.
The image can be depicted as an overexcited hound out of breath chasing its tail—while an alert hound calmly sniffs out the trail—highlighting purposeful calm over frantic effort.

Idiom meaning in English: Repeated mistakes or losses.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “হাঁড়ি হাঁড়ি ভাঙ্গা” translates to “Breaking pot after pot” in English. It depicts ceaseless waste or conflict, smashing container after container without end.
The image can be depicted as a furious figure smashing an army of clay pots in succession—each shattering to dust—illustrating relentless destruction.

Actual idiom: হারে ঘাড়া দিয়ে কে, ভড়া বয়ে কে যায়।
Literal Translation: Who puts the neck in the yoke, who carries the load?
English Pronounciation: Hare ghara diye ke, bhora boye ke jay
Idiom meaning in English: Few take responsibility, many enjoy benefits.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
"The Bengali idiom “হারে কারো সাহায্য নেই, জয়েও কাউকে থাকে না” (sense applied for “হারে ঘাড়া দিয়ে কে, ভ়াড়া বয়ে কে যায়”) translates to “In defeat no one helps you; in victory you need no one” in English. It remarks on the loneliness of both extreme outcomes.
The image can be depicted as a fallen athlete lying alone on the track and, in a separate frame, the champion standing solitary on the podium—underscoring isolation at both ends."

Actual idiom: হাতে পাওয়া অল্পও ভাল, পরের হাতে বেশি কিছু নয়।
Literal Translation: A little in hand is better than much in others’ hands.
English Pronounciation: Hate pawa olpo-o bhalo, porer hate beshi kichu noy
Idiom meaning in English: What you have is better than what others have.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “হাতে পাওয়া অল্পও ভাল, পরের হাতে বেশি কিছু নয়” translates to “Better a little in hand than much in someone else’s” in English. It echoes “A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.”
The image can be depicted as a hand clutching a single ripe fruit while two wither on a distant branch—emphasizing the security of the certain over the promise of abundance.

Actual idiom: হাতের ঢিল চুরলে আর ফেরত আসে না
Literal Translation: A stone thrown from the hand never returns.
English Pronounciation: Hater dhil churle ar ferot ashe na
Idiom meaning in English: Once done, some actions cannot be undone.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “হাতের ঢিল চুরলে আর ফেরত আসে না” translates to “A thrown stone never returns” in English. It warns that words or deeds, once done, cannot be undone.
The image can be depicted as a stone arcing into the sky, with the thrower reaching in vain—illustrating the irrevocability of action.

Literal Translation: The stone has already been thrown.
Idiom meaning in English: What’s done is done; can’t be taken back.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “হাতের ঢিল ছোড়া হয়েছে” translates to “The stone in the hand has already been thrown” in English. This proverb suggests that once an action is set in motion, it cannot be stopped or undone—regret comes too late.
The image can be depicted as a hand opening into empty air just after releasing a stone, while the stone arcs away against the sky—illustrating that the deed is done and cannot be recalled.

Literal Translation: There’s no comfort in ill-gotten gains.
Idiom meaning in English: Ill-gotten gains bring no peace.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “হরামের আরাম নেই” translates to “Ill-gotten comforts bring no peace” in English. It teaches that benefits seized through wrongdoing breed guilt and unrest.
The image can be depicted as a thief sleeping uneasily on a bed of stolen coins, shadowy faces haunting his dreams—capturing torment born of dishonor.

Literal Translation: Makes you laugh, also makes you sad.
Idiom meaning in English: Something is both amusing and sad at once.
Descriptive Meaning(Human Annotation):
The Bengali idiom “হাসিও পায়, দুঃখও হয়” translates to “One gains laughter and also sorrow” in English. It observes that life’s joys and pains are inseparable companions.
The image can be depicted as a carnival scene split by a crack: on one side children laugh on a carousel, on the other, somber figures emerge from a dark tunnel—showing duality of experience.
